ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ORDINANCE NO. 1-2003
AN ORDINANCE ENACTING AND ADOPTING A SUPPLEMENT TO THE CODE OF ORDINANCES FOR
THE CITY OF BEDFORD
WHEREAS, American Legal Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati, Ohio, has
completed the 2002 supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the City of Bedford,
which supplement contains all ordinances of a general and permanent nature
enacted since the prior supplement to the Code of Ordinances of this Political
Subdivision; and
WHEREAS, American Legal Publishing Corporation has recommended the revision or
addition of certain sections of the Code of Ordinances which are based on or
make reference to sections to the Indiana Code; and
WHEREAS, it is the intent of the Legislative Authority to accept these updated
sections in accordance with the changes of the laws of the State of Indiana;
and
WHEREAS, it is necessary to provide for the usual daily operation of the
municipality and for the immediate preservation of the public peace, health,
safety and general welfare of the municipality that this ordinance take effect
at an early date;
   Section 1. That the 2002 supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the
Political Subdivision as submitted by American Legal Publishing Corporation of
Cincinnati, Ohio, and as attached hereto be and the same is hereby adopted by
reference as if set out in its entirety.
   Section 2. Such supplement shall be deemed published as of the day of its
adoption and approval by the Legislative Authority and the Clerk of the
Political Subdivision is hereby authorized and ordered to insert such
supplement into the copy of the Code of Ordinances kept on file in the Office
of the Clerk.
PASSED AND ADOPTED BY THE COMMON COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF BEDFORD, INDIANA THIS
11th day of February, 2003.
   John A. Williams /s/
   Presiding Officer
ATTEST:
Donna M. Brumbaugh /s/
Clerk-Treasurer
   Presented by me to the Mayor of the City of Bedford, Indiana, on the 11th
day of February, 2003.
   Donna M. Brumbaugh /s/
   Clerk-Treasurer
   This ordinance approved and signed by me this 11th day of February, 2003.
   John A. Williams /s/
   Mayor
ATTEST:
Donna M. Brumbaugh /s/
Clerk-Treasurer

ORDINANCE NO. 13-2005
AN ORDINANCE ENACTING AND ADOPTING A SUPPLEMENT TO THE CODE OF ORDINANCES FOR
THE CITY OF BEDFORD
WHEREAS, American Legal Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati, Ohio, has
completed the 2004 supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the City of Bedford,
which supplement contains all ordinances of a general and permanent nature
enacted since the prior supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the City of
Bedford; and
WHEREAS, American Legal Publishing Corporation has recommended the revision or
addition of certain sections of the Code of Ordinances which are based on or
make reference to sections to the Indiana Code; and
WHEREAS, it is the intent of the Common Council of the City of Bedford to
accept these updated sections in accordance with the changes of the laws of the
State of Indiana; and
WHEREAS, it is necessary to provide for the usual daily operation of the
municipality and for the immediate preservation of the public peace, health,
safety and general welfare of the municipality that this ordinance take effect
at an early date;
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE COMMON COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF BEDFORD,
INDIANA:
   Section 1. That the 2004 supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the City of
Bedford as submitted by American Legal Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati,
Ohio, and as attached hereto, be and the same is hereby adopted by reference as
if set out in its entirety.
   Section 2. Such supplement shall be deemed published as of the day of its
adoption and approval by the Common Council and the Clerk-Treasurer of the City
of Bedford is hereby authorized and ordered to insert such supplement into the
copy of the Code of Ordinances kept on file in the Office of the Clerk-
Treasurer.
   PASSED AND ADOPTED BY THE COMMON COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF BEDFORD, INDIANA
THIS 12th day of April, 2005.
   Joe D. Klumpp /s/
   Presiding Officer

ORDINANCE NO. 5-2010
   AN ORDINANCE ENACTING AND ADOPTING A SUPPLEMENT TO THE CODE OF ORDINANCES
FOR THE CITY OF BEDFORD, STATE OF INDIANA
WHEREAS, American Legal Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati, Ohio, has
completed the 2009 supplement to the code of Ordinances of the City of Bedford,
which supplement contains all ordinances of a general and permanent nature
enacted since the prior supplement to the Code of Ordinances of this Political
Subdivision; and
WHEREAS, American legal Publishing Corporation has recommended the revision or
addition of certain sections of the Code of Ordinances which are based on or
make reference to sections of the Indiana Code; and
WHEREAS, it is the intent of the Common Council of the City of Bedford to
accept these updated sections in accordance with the changes of the law of the
State of Indiana; and
WHEREAS, it is necessary to provide for the usual daily operation of the City
of Bedford and for the immediate preservation of the public peace, health,
safety and general welfare of the municipality that this ordinance take effect
at an early date;
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE COMMON COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF BEDFORD:
Section 1.   That the 2009 supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the City of
Bedford as submitted by American Legal Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati,
Ohio, and as attached hereto, be and the same is hereby adopted by reference as
if set out in its entirety.
Section 2.   Such supplement shall be deemed published as of the day of its
adoption and approval by the Common Council and the Clerk-Treasurer of the City
of Bedford is hereby authorized and ordered to insert such supplement into the
copy of the Code of Ordinances kept on file in the Office of the Clerk-
Treasurer.
Section 3.   This ordinance is declared to be an emergency measure necessary
for the immediate preservation of the peace, health, safety and general welfare
of the people of the City of Bedford, and shall take effect at the earliest
date provided by law.
PASSED AND ADOPTED BY THE COMMON COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF BEDFORD, INDIANA, this
13th day of April, 2010.
Shawna M. Girgis /s/
Presiding Officer

ORDINANCE NO. 15-2011
   AN ORDINANCE ENACTING AND ADOPTING A SUPPLEMENT TO THE CODE OF ORDINANCES
FOR THE CITY OF BEDFORD, STATE OF INDIANA AND DECLARING AN EMERGENCY
WHEREAS, American Legal Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati, Ohio, has
completed the 2010 supplement to the code of Ordinances of the City of Bedford,
which supplement contains all ordinances of a general and permanent nature
enacted since the prior supplement to the Code of Ordinances of this Political
Subdivision; and
WHEREAS, American legal Publishing Corporation has recommended the revision or
addition of certain sections of the Code of Ordinances which are based on or
make reference to sections of the Indiana Code; and
WHEREAS, it is the intent of the Legislative Authority to accept these updated
sections in accordance with the changes of the law of the State of Indiana; and
WHEREAS, it is necessary to provide for the usual daily operation of the
municipality and for the immediate preservation of the public peace, health,
safety and general welfare of the municipality that this ordinance take effect
at an early date;
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE LEGISLATIVE AUTHORITY OF THE POLITICAL
SUBDIVISION OF THE CITY OF BEDFORD:
Section 1.   That the 2010 supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the
Political Subdivision as submitted by American Legal Publishing Corporation of
Cincinnati, Ohio, and as attached hereto, be and the same is hereby adopted by
reference as if set out in its entirety.
Section 2.   Such supplement shall be deemed published as of the day of its
adoption and approval by the Legislative Authority and the Clerk of the
Political Subdivision is hereby authorized and ordered to insert such
supplement into the copy of the code of Ordinances kept on file in the Office
of the Clerk.
Section 3.   This ordinance is declared to be an emergency measure necessary
for the immediate preservation of the peace, health, safety and general welfare
of the people of this municipality, and shall take effect at the earliest date
provided by law.
PASSED AND ADOPTED BY THE COMMON COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF BEDFORD, INDIANA, this
9th day of August, 2011.

§ 10.01 TITLE OF CODE.
   This code shall be known and may be designated and cited as the "Bedford
City Code." The codification has been made in one ordinance under appropriate
titles, chapters, and sections by authority of the laws of the state.
('67 Code, § 1.01 (A))
Statutory reference:
   Codification of ordinances, see I.C. 36-1-5-1 et seq.
§ 10.02 INTERPRETATION.
   (A)   Unless otherwise provided herein, or by law or implication required,
the same rules of construction, definition, and application shall govern the
interpretation of this code as those governing the interpretation of the
Indiana Code.
   (B)   Where a section of this code is followed by a reference to the Indiana
Code, the reference indicates that the section is analogous or similar to the
cited sections in the Indiana Code. Footnotes, cross-references, and other
comments are by way of explanation only and should not be deemed a part of the
text of any section.
('67 Code, § 1.01(B), (C))
§ 10.03 APPLICATION TO FUTURE LEGISLATION.
   All provisions of Title I not incompatible with future legislation shall
apply to ordinances hereafter adopted which amend or supplement this code
unless otherwise specifically provided.
('67 Code, § 1.02)
§ 10.04 CAPTIONS.
   Headings and captions used in this code other than the title, chapter, and
section numbers are employed for reference purposes only and shall not be
deemed a part of the text of any section.
('67 Code, § 1.03)
§ 10.05 DEFINITIONS.
   (A)   General rule. Words and phrases shall be taken in their plain,
ordinary, and usual sense. But technical words and phrases having a peculiar
and appropriate meaning in law shall be understood according to their technical
import. (I.C. 1-1-4-1)
(I.C. 1-1-4-1)
   (B)   For the purpose of this code the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   AND or OR. Includes the other as if written AND/OR.
   CITY, MUNICIPAL CORPORATION, or MUNICIPALITY. The City of Bedford, Indiana.
('67 Code, § 1.04(H), (B))
   COUNCIL. The Common Council of Bedford, Indiana.
   I.C. Reference is to the Indiana Code.
   MAY. Is permissive.
   MONTH. A calendar month.
('67 Code, § 1.04(J))
   MUNICIPAL CORPORATION. See CITY.
   MUNICIPALITY. See CITY.
   OWNER. Applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner,
tenant in common, tenant in partnership, or joint tenant of the whole or a part
of the building or land, either alone or with others.
   PERSON. Includes a natural person, partnership, or a corporate body or any
body of persons, corporate or incorporate. Whenever used in any clause
prescribing and imposing a penalty, PERSON, as applied to any unincorporated
entity, shall mean the partners or members thereof, and as applied to
corporations, the officers thereof.
('67 Code, § 1.04(E), (F))
   PERSONAL PROPERTY. Every species of property except real property.
   POPULATION. The population according to the most recent federal special or
decennial census. This definition applies even if the reference is to the most
recent federal decennial census.
   PROPERTY. Real and personal property.
   REAL PROPERTY. Lands, tenements, and hereditaments and all chattels real.
   SHALL. Is mandatory.
   SIDEWALK. That portion of a street between the curb lines of the lateral
lines of a roadway and the adjacent property lines intended for the use of
pedestrians.
   STATE or THIS STATE. The State of Indiana.
('67 Code, § 1.04(1))
   STREET. Except as provided in the traffic code, the entire width between
property lines of every way or place of whatever nature when any part thereof
is open to the use of the public, as a matter of right.
   THIS CODE or THIS CODE OF ORDINANCES. The Bedford City Code as adopted by
ordinance, and as hereafter modified by amendment, revision, and by the
adoption of new titles, chapters, or sections.
('67 Code, § 1.04(A))
   YEAR. A calendar year, unless otherwise expressed.
(I.C. 1-1-4-1)
§ 10.06 RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.
   (A)   Gender.  Words denoting the masculine gender shall be deemed to
include the feminine and neuter genders.
   (B)   Singular; plural.  Words in the singular shall include the plural, and
words in the plural shall include the singular.
   (C)   General terms. A general term following specific enumeration of terms
is not to be limited to the class enumerated unless expressly so limited.
   (D)   Tenses. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as
well as the past and present.
('67 Code, § 1.04(C), (D), (G), (K))
§ 10.07 COMPUTATION OF TIME.
   Unless otherwise specifically provided, the time within which an act is
required by law to be done shall be computed by excluding the first day and
including the last. The last day shall be excluded if it is a Sunday or
holiday.
('67 Code, § 1.04(I))
§ 10.08 REFERENCES TO OTHER SECTIONS.
   Whenever in one section reference is made to another section hereof, the
reference shall extend and apply to the section referred to as subsequently
amended, revised, recodified, or renumbered unless the subject matter is
changed or materially altered by the amendment or revision.
('67 Code, § 1.06)
§ 10.09 REFERENCES TO OFFICES.
   Reference to a public office or officer shall be deemed to apply to any
office, officer, or employee of the city exercising the powers, duties, or
functions contemplated in the provision, irrespective of any transfer of
functions or change in the official title of the functionary.
('67 Code, § 1.07)
§ 10.10 ERRORS OR OMISSIONS.
   If a manifest error is discovered, consisting of the misspelling of any
words; the omission of any word or words necessary to express the intention of
the provisions affected; the use of a word or words to which no meaning can be
attached; or the use of a word or words when another word or words was clearly
intended to express the intent, the spelling shall be corrected and the word or
words supplied, omitted, or substituted that will conform with the manifest
intention, and the provisions shall have the same effect as though the correct
words were contained in the text as originally published. No alteration shall
be made or permitted if any question exists regarding the nature or extent of
the error.
('67 Code, § 1.08)
§ 10.11 REVIVOR; EFFECT OF REPEAL.
   Whenever an ordinance is repealed, which repealed a former ordinance, the
original ordinance shall not thereby be revived, unless it shall be so
expressly provided.
(I.C. 1-1-5-1)
§ 10.12 CONFLICTING PROVISIONS.
   If the provisions of different codes, chapters, or sections of the codified
ordinances conflict with or contravene each other, the provisions bearing the
latest passage date shall prevail. If the conflicting provisions bear the same
passage date, the conflict shall be construed so as to be consistent with the
meaning or legal effect of the subject matter taken as a whole.
§ 10.13 SEVERABILITY.
   Each chapter, section, or, whenever divisible, part of a section of this
code is hereby declared to be separable, and the invalidity of any chapter,
section, or divisible part of a section, shall not be construed to affect the
validity of any other chapter, section, or part of a section of this code.
('67 Code, § 1.05)
§ 10.14 ORDINANCES REPEALED.
   This code, from and after its effective date, shall contain all of the
provisions of a general nature pertaining to the subjects herein enumerated and
embraced. All prior ordinances pertaining to the subjects treated by this code
shall be deemed repealed from and after the effective date of this code.
§ 10.15 ORDINANCES UNAFFECTED.
   All ordinances of a temporary or special nature and all other ordinances
pertaining to subjects not embraced in this code shall remain in full force and
effect unless herein repealed expressly or by necessary implication.
§ 10.16 ORDINANCES SAVED.
   Whenever an ordinance by its nature either authorizes or enables the
legislative body or a certain county officer or employee to make additional
ordinances or regulations for the purpose of carrying out the intent of the
ordinance, all ordinances and regulations of a similar nature serving that
purpose effected prior to the codification and not inconsistent thereto, shall
remain in effect and are saved.
§ 10.17 AMENDMENTS TO CODE.
   Any chapter, section, or division amended or added to this code by
ordinances passed subsequent to this code may be numbered in accordance with
the numbering system of this code and printed for inclusion herein. Any
chapter, section, or division repealed by subsequent ordinances may be excluded
from this code by omission from reprinted pages. Subsequent ordinances as
printed or omitted shall be prima facie evidence of the subsequent ordinances
until the legislative body of the county adopts a new code of ordinances.
§ 10.18 CITY FLOWER.
   The chrysanthemum is hereby declared to be the official flower of the city.
('67 Code, § 3.01) (Ord. 12-1960, passed 11-1-60)
§ 10.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this code for which another penalty is not
specifically provided shall be fined not more than $2500 for each offense.
('67 Code, § 1.09)
Cross-reference:
   Ordinance Violations Bureau applicable to chapters in Titles VII, IX, and
XIII see §
32.135(A)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 30.01 GENERAL ORGANIZATION.
   The government of the city shall consist of four branches, those being:
   (A)   Executive Branch.
(I.C. 36-4-5)
   (B)   Legislative Branch.
(I.C. 36-4-6)
   (C)   Fiscal Branch.
(I.C. 36-4-10)
   (D)   Statutory Boards and Commissions.
(Ord. 22-1983, passed 8-29-83)
EXECUTIVE BRANCH
§ 30.10 MAYOR.
   The Mayor is the head of the executive branch. He shall faithfully perform
the duties and responsibilities contained in I.C. 36-4-5 and other statutes of
the state.
(Ord. 22-1983, passed 8-29-83)
§ 30.11 DEPARTMENTS UNDER THE CONTROL OF THE BOARD OF PUBLIC WORKS AND SAFETY.
   (A)   There is hereby established a Board of Public Works and Safety within
the executive branch. Such board shall be the chief administrative body of the
city and shall have control of the day-to-day operations of the following
executive departments which are hereby established:
      (1)   Police Department.
      (2)   Fire Department.
      (3)   Street Department.
      (4)   Sanitation Department.
      (5)   Department of Transportation.
      (6)   Department of Cemeteries.
      (7)   Waterworks Department.
      (8)   Sewerage Department.
      (9)   Department of Administration.
   (B)   The members of the Board of Public Works and Safety shall be the Mayor
and two voters of the city who shall be chosen by the Mayor and serve at his
pleasure.
   (C)   The Board of Public Works and Safety may, by resolution, delegate to
the Mayor, the authority to manage the day-to-day operations and supervise the
personnel of the departments under its control.
(Ord. 22-1983, passed 8-29-83)
§ 30.12 OTHER DEPARTMENTS.
   (A)   There is hereby established a Department of Law pursuant to I.C. 36-4-
9-12.
   (B)   There is hereby established a Department of Parks and Recreation to be
controlled by the Board of Parks and Recreation pursuant to I.C. 36-10.
   (C)   There is hereby established a Department of Planning and Development
under I.C. 36-7.
(Ord. 22-1983, passed 8-29-83)
§ 30.13 DEPARTMENT HEADS.
   The Chiefs of the Police and Fire Department and the heads of the
departments of Law, Waterworks, Sewerage, Transportation, Streets, Sanitation,
and Administration shall be appointed by the Mayor and serve at his pleasure
(I.C. 36-4-9). Pursuant to I.C. 36-4-9-2, the Mayor shall appoint the heads of
the Departments of Parks and Recreation, and Planning and Development with the
approval of the Statutory Board or Commission operating the department. Such
appointees serve at the pleasure of the Mayor (I.C. 36-4-11-2). The head of the
Department of Parks and Recreation shall also be the head of the Department of
Cemeteries. The head of the division of Planning and Zoning shall also serve as
the Commissioner of Buildings.
(Ord. 22-1983, passed 8-29-83)
§ 30.14 ABILITY OF DEPARTMENTS TO HIRE EMPLOYEES AND PURCHASE MATERIALS.
   Subject to the appropriation power of the Common Council, the foregoing
departments shall have the ability to hire such employees, and purchase or
contract for such materials or services, as the Board of Public Works and
Safety or other governing board or commission deems necessary to perform their
public function.
(Ord. 22-1983, passed 8-29-83)
Cross-reference:
   Board of Public Works designated as purchasing agency, see §
34.06
LEGISLATIVE BRANCH
§ 30.20 AUTHORITY OF COMMON COUNCIL.
   The legislative branch of the city is the Common Council. The Council shall
have exclusive authority to adopt ordinances and appropriate tax monies
received by the city, and to perform other necessary, and desirable legislative
functions (I.C. 36-4-6).
(Ord. 22-1983, passed 8-29-83)
§ 30.21 CLERK-TREASURER.
   The Clerk-Treasurer shall be the Clerk of the Council and shall perform the
duties prescribed by I.C. 36-4-6-9 and such others as the Council may direct.
(Ord. 22-1983, passed 8-29-83)
§ 30.22 MEETING DATE AND TIME.
   The regular meeting date and time for the Common Council shall be at 7:00
p.m. on the third Monday of each month.
(Ord. 22-1983, passed 8-29-83; Am. Ord. 5-2001, passed 4-10-01; Am. Ord. 2-
2020, passed 5-18-20)
§ 30.23 PRESIDING OFFICER; RULES.
   The Mayor, or in his absence the President of the Council, shall be the
Presiding Officer of the Council pursuant to I.C. 36-4-6-8, and meetings shall
be conducted pursuant to the applicable statutes (I.C. 36-4-6-10 through 36-4-
6-17) and in accordance with the following rules which are hereby adopted as a
part of this chapter.
   (A)   Order of business.  The order of business to be followed at a meeting
of the Common Council shall be as follows:
      (1)   Calling to order.
      (2)   Roll call by Clerk-Treasurer.
      (3)   Reading of minutes and approval.
      (4)   Public participation.
      (5)   Reports from committees, Commissions, or Boards.
      (6)   Unfinished business.
      (7)   New business.
      (8)   Miscellaneous business.
      (9)   Adjournment.
   (B)   Contempt and disorder in the council room. No person shall use violent
or contemptuous language, behave in a disorderly manner, or refuse to obey the
orders of the Mayor or Presiding Officer in the council room while the Common
Council is in session.
   (C)   Introduction and adoption of ordinances and resolutions.
      (1)   All ordinances shall be regularly filed with the Clerk-Treasurer.
      (2)   All ordinances shall be read three times before being passed, and
no ordinance shall pass on the same day in which it is introduced unless the
provisions of I.C. 36-4-6-13 are complied with. Reference the title of a
proposed ordinance shall be considered read unless a literal reading is
required by state statute. All ordinances shall be posted outside the meeting
room prior to their consideration by the Council.
      (3)   Resolutions shall be subject to the same rules and method of
introduction as ordinances, except that resolutions may be adopted after only
one reading.
      (4)   On the passage or adoption of any ordinance or resolution the yeas
and nays shall be taken and entered in the record, and the ordinance shall be
processed in accordance with I.C. 36-4-6-14 through 36-4-6-17.
   (D)   Questions of order. The Mayor or Presiding Officer shall decide all
questions of order. He shall decide whether any question submitted to the
Council for adoption or rejection is decided in the affirmative or negative.
   (E)   Appeal from decision of Presiding Officer.  From any decision of the
Presiding Officer any member may appeal to the Council. The appeal shall be by
motion duly made and seconded.
   (F)   Parliamentary procedure. For procedural matters not otherwise
controlled by terms of this chapter, the Council shall conduct its business in
accordance with Robert’s Rules of Order.
(Ord. 22-1983, passed 8-29-83)
§ 30.24 REDISTRICTING OF COUNCILMANIC DISTRICTS.
   Redistricting of councilmanic districts shall be done at one time every ten
years in accordance with I.C. 36-4-6-4 and 36-4-6-5.
(Ord. 22-1983, passed 8-29-83)
FISCAL BRANCH
§ 30.30 FISCAL OFFICER; DEPUTIES.
   (A)   The Clerk-Treasurer is the fiscal officer of the city and the head of
the fiscal branch. He shall perform the duties assigned by I.C. 36-4-10.
   (B)   The Clerk-Treasurer is hereby authorized, pursuant to I.C. 36-4-11-4,
to appoint two Deputy Clerk- Treasurers. Such deputies shall work under the
exclusive direction of the Clerk-Treasurer, and serve at the pleasure of the
Clerk-Treasurer.
(Ord. 22-1983, passed 8-29-83)
§ 30.31 ADMINISTRATION OF CITY’S UTILITIES.
   The Clerk-Treasurer shall furnish space within his or her office for the
administration and records of the city’s utilities. The Clerk-Treasurer and the
First Deputy Clerk- Treasurer shall be compensated for services he or she
renders to the city’s utilities.
(Ord. 22-1983, passed 8-29-83)
§ 30.32 CLERK-TREASURER AUTHORIZED DRAFTS.
   (A) The City Clerk-Treasurer is hereby authorized to issue a draft payable
to the Recorder of the county to pay for recordings, without first filing a
claim for such payments.
   (B)   The City Clerk-Treasurer is hereby authorized to issue drafts from
time to time for the payment of the mailing costs, of the city utilities, to
the U.S. Postmaster, and postage for each department as needed, without further
authorization.
   (C)   The Clerk-Treasurer is hereby authorized to issue drafts from time to
time for the payment of the employees of the city which the payments constitute
the city payroll, without further authorization.
   (D)   The Clerk-Treasurer is hereby authorized to issue drafts from time to
time for the refund of water meter deposits to the person, persons or other
entity entitled to receive the same, without further authorization.
   (E)   The Clerk-Treasurer is hereby authorized to issue drafts from time to
time for payment of group health, hospitalization, dental and life insurance,
worker’s compensation, unemployment, sales and gross income taxes, retirement,
and all payroll deductions, including electronic transfer without the further
authorization.
   (F)   The Clerk-Treasurer is hereby authorized to issue drafts from time to
time for the payment of invoices presented to the city for materials,
equipment, goods and services previously authorized by the Board by accepting a
valid bid, quote, or contract for such material, equipment, goods and services
without further authorization.
   (G)   The Clerk-Treasurer is hereby authorized to issue drafts from time to
time for the payment of utility bills incurred by the city without further
authorization.
   (H)   The Clerk-Treasurer is hereby authorized to issue drafts from time to
time for the registration fees and expenses for schooling and conferences
incurred by the persons who have permission to attend.
   (I)   The Clerk-Treasurer is hereby authorized to issue drafts from time to
time for registration fees for vehicles, titles, and any excise tax that might
be due.
   (J)   The Clerk-Treasurer is hereby authorized to issue drafts from time to
time for the payment of expenses that must be paid because of emergency
circumstances.
(Ord. 1-2001, passed 1-9-01)
§ 30.33 AUTHORIZATION OF ELECTRONIC FUNDS TRANSFER.
   (A)   The Clerk-Treasurer is authorized to complete all forms and
applications necessary to cause the State Auditor to distribute funds to the
city’s designated depository by use of electronic funds transfer.
   (B)   The funds from which the electronic funds transfers may be made to the
city are the following:
      (1)   Motor Vehicle Highway.
      (2)   Local Road and Street.
      (3)   Local Road and Street P1260-1997.
      (4)   Motor Vehicle Highway Accelerated #1.
      (5)   Motor Vehicle Highway Accelerated #2.
      (5)   ABC Gallonage.
      (6)   Cigarette Tax - General Fund.
      (7)   Cigarette Tax - CCIF.
   (C)   The Clerk-Treasurer is required to maintain adequate documentation of
all transactions involving the use of electronic funds transfer so that the
same may be audited as provided by law.
(Ord. 12-2001, passed 5-8-01)
STATUTORY BOARDS OR COMMISSIONS
§ 30.40 PENSION BOARDS OF TRUSTEES.
   (A)   There shall be a Police Pension Board of Trustees to perform certain
duties prescribed by I.C. 36-8-6 and 36-8-8 concerning the statutory pensions
of city police officers.
   (B)   There shall be a Fire Fighters Pension Board of Trustees to perform
certain duties prescribed by I.C. 36-8-7 and 36-8-8 concerning the statutory
pensions of city fire fighters.
(Ord. 22-1983, passed 8-29-83)
§ 30.41 ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION.
   There is established an Economic Development Commission pursuant to I.C. 36-
7. Said Commission shall have and exercise the powers and duties now and
hereafter prescribed by law, and it shall perform and exercise those duties and
powers in the manner now and hereafter prescribed by law. All of the territory
included within the corporate limits of the city shall constitute a taxing
district for the purpose of levying and collecting special taxes for the
purposes as provided by law.
(Ord. 22-1983, passed 8-29-83)
§ 30.42 DEPARTMENT OF REDEVELOPMENT.
   (A)   The Common Council now deems it to be in the best interest of the city
and its citizens to afford a maximum opportunity for rehabilitation,
redevelopment or economic development of areas by private enterprise and the
city by establishing a department of redevelopment.
   (B)   The Common Council hereby establishes the Department of Redevelopment
of the city. The Department will be controlled by a board of five members known
as the Bedford Redevelopment Commission.
   (C)   Pursuant to I.C. 36-7-14 and I.C. 36-7-25 (the Act), all of the
territory within the corporate boundaries of the city will be a special taxing
district to be known as the Bedford Redevelopment District for the purpose of
levying and collecting special benefit taxes for redevelopment and economic
development purposes as provided in the Act. The Common Council finds and
determines that all of the taxable property within this special taxing district
will be considered to be benefitted by the redevelopment projects and economic
development projects carried out under the Act to the extent of the special
taxes levied under the Act.
   (D)   (1)   The Mayor shall appoint three of the five members of the
Commission.
      (2)   The Common Council shall appoint two of the five members of the
Commission.
      (3)   The term of office of the members of the Commission shall commence
from the date of their appointment and expire on January 1, 2007.
(Ord. 8-2005, passed 3-8-05)
§ 30.43 HOUSING AUTHORITY.
   (A)   Pursuant to I.C. 36-7, the Common Council, upon due notice having held
a public hearing, an opportunity to be heard was granted to all residents and
taxpayers of the city and to all other interested persons having considered the
testimony and evidence presented at said public hearing and their own personal
knowledge of dwelling accommodations and need for a housing authority to
function in the city, the Common Council finds, determines, and declares that:
unsanitary and unsafe inhabited dwelling accommodations exist in the city; and
there is a shortage of safe and sanitary dwelling accommodations in the city
available to persons of low income at rentals they can afford; and there is a
need for a housing authority to function in the city.
   (B)   The Housing Authority established in division (A) above shall be
composed of seven members appointed by the Mayor, one of whom must be a
resident of a housing project under the jurisdiction of the Housing Authority
and no more than four of whom may be of the same political party, in accordance
with I.C. 36-7-18-5.
(Res. 22-1965, passed 9-13-65; Am. Ord. 22-1983, passed 8-29-83; Am. Ord. 1-
2008, passed 1-8-08)

and described as follows.

of Commissioners of the county by the ordinance adopted January 18, 1958, as
amended.

composed of Shawswick Township Precincts 5A, 5B and 7A as established by the
Board of Commissioners of the county by the ordinance adopted January 18, 1958,
as amended.
   (D)   Councilmanic District No. 4. Councilmanic District No. 4 shall be
composed of Shawswick Township Precincts 3, 4 and 6 as established by the Board
of Commissioners of the county by ordinance adopted January 18, 1958, as
amended.
   (E)   Councilmanic District No. 5. Councilmanic District No. 5 shall be
composed of Shawswick Township Precincts 8, 9 and 10 as established by the
Board of Commissioners of the county by the ordinance adopted January 18, 1958,
as amended.
(‘67 Code, §31.02) (Ord. 9-1958, passed 12-2-58; Am. Ord. 33-1974, passed 12-

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 31.01 ELECTED OFFICIALS.
   The elected officers of the city shall be the Mayor; the Clerk-Treasurer;
and the members of Common Council.
(‘67 Code, § 30.01) (Ord. 1-1977, passed 1-11-77)
Statutory reference:
   Mayor, see I.C. 36-4-5-1 et seq.
   Clerk-Treasurer, see I.C. 36-4-10-1 et seq.
   Common Council, see I.C. 36-4-6-1 et seq.
§ 31.02 EXECUTIVE AUTHORITY OF CITY.
   The executive and administrative authority of the city shall be vested in
the Mayor, Clerk-Treasurer, any departments that are provided for by state law,
and in other officers that may be appointed by virtue of state law.
(‘67 Code, § 32.01)
Statutory reference:
   Executive, administrative powers and duties of city, see I.C. 36-4-4-3
§ 31.03 BONDS REQUIRED.
   The officers named below shall execute a bond, conditioned for the faithful
performance of the duties of their respective office in the amounts set forth
opposite their office or position:
   (A)   Individual Position Bonds.
      (1)   Clerk-Treasurer: $300,000.
      (2)   Secretary, Police Pension Fund: $15,000.
      (3)   Park Superintendent: $15,000.
      (4)   Golf Professional/Manager: $15,000.
      (5)   Water and Sewer Superintendent: $15,000.
   (B)   One Faithful Performance Blanket Position Bond for all positions in
the city:
      (1)   City Fire Department: $2,500.
      (2)   City Police Department: $2,500.
      (3)   City Street Department: $2,500.
      (4)   Water and Sewer Department: $2,500.
      (5)   Clerk-Treasurer’s Office: $2,500.
      (6)   Board of Public Works and Safety: $2,500.
      (7)   Board of Parks and Recreation: $2,500.
      (8)   City Parks Department: $2,500.
      (9)   City Planning Department: $2,500.
      (10)   City Transportation Department: $2,500.
      (11)   City Administration: $2,500.
      (12)   City Common Council: $2,500.
(‘67 Code, §30.03) (Ord. 1-1977, passed 1-11-77; Am. Ord. 37-1983, passed 12-
28-83; Am. Ord. 28-2009, passed 9-8-09; Am. Ord. 8-2018, passed 4-10-18)

CITY PLAN COMMISSION
§ 32.015 ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERS.
   (A)   There is hereby established a City Plan Commission consisting of seven
members as follows: the municipal legislative body shall appoint three persons,
who must be elected or appointed municipal officials or employees in the
municipal government, as members; the municipal executive shall appoint four
citizen members, of whom no more than two may be of the same political party in
accordance with I.C. 36-7-4-203(b).
   (B)   Each citizen member shall be appointed because of his knowledge and
experience in community affairs, his awareness of the social, economic,
agricultural, and industrial problems of the area, and his interest in the
development and integration of the area. A citizen member may not hold other
elective or appointive office in municipal, county, or state government, except
in the case of an area plan commission membership on the school board or park
board. A citizen member must be a resident of the jurisdictional area of the
Plan Commission.
(‘67 Code, § 33.50) (Ord. 7-1945, passed 8-7-45; Am. Ord. 2-2008, passed 1-8-
08)
Statutory reference:
   Establishment of City Plan Commission, see I.C. 36-7-4-200 et seq.
   Qualifications of citizen members, see I.C. 36-7-4-216
§ 32.016 TERM OF OFFICE.
   (A)   The first five citizen members of the City Plan Commission so
appointed shall hold office respectively as follows: one for a term of two
years, two for a term of three years, and two for a term of four years, from
and after January 1 of the year of their appointment. Annually thereafter, on
or before February 1 of each year, the Mayor shall appoint a Commissioner to
fill the vacancy caused by the expiration of the term of office of any
Commissioner, and the Commissioner shall hold office for the term of four years
from January 1 of the year of his appointment. If any vacancy shall exist on
the Commission, caused by resignation or otherwise of a citizen member, the
Mayor shall appoint a Commissioner for the residue of the term.
   (B)   As soon as the City Plan Commission shall have been established, the
Common Council and the Board of Parks and Recreation shall each select a member
of their respective boards to serve on the Plan Commission, their terms to
expire with the termination of their respective terms of office to which they
may have been elected or appointed. Thereafter, whenever a vacancy occurs on
the Commission, by resignation or otherwise of a member of the Common Council,
the park board, or the board of directors for public utilities or board of
trustees for utilities created under I.C. 8-1-11.1, each of these bodies shall
immediately select one of its members to fill the vacancy and to serve during
his term of office in the city government. The certificate of the Clerk of the
Common Council or the Secretary of the Board of Parks and Recreation of any
selection shall be transmitted to the City Plan Commission and made a part of
their records.
   (C)   The President of the Board of Public Works and Safety and the City
Engineer shall be ex-officio members of the Plan Commission. All members of the
Commission shall serve without compensation, except actual expense
reimbursement which shall be subject to approval by the Mayor.
   (D)   No Commissioner shall be removed from office, except upon charges
first filed in writing with the City Plan Commission, and after a hearing
thereon before the Commission. Nothing shall be deemed sufficient cause for
removal, except inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office.
(‘67 Code, § 33.50(B)) (Ord. 7-1945, passed 8-7-45)
§ 32.017 OFFICERS.
   The City Plan Commission shall choose, annually, at its first regular
meeting in February, one of its members to act as President of the Commission
and another of its members as Vice-President. The Vice-President shall perform
all of the duties of the President during his absence or disability.
(‘67 Code, § 33.50(C)) (Ord. 7-1945, passed 8-7-45)
§ 32.018 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The City Plan Commission shall have the powers and perform the duties
provided in I.C. 36-7-4-400 et seq., and all acts amendatory thereof and
supplemental thereto.
(‘67 Code, § 33.50(E)) (Ord. 7-1945, passed 8-7-45)
Cross-reference:
   Approval of subdivision plats required, see §
152.01
   Improvement location permit appeals, see §
151.04
§ 32.019 RECORDS.
   All records of the City Plan Commission shall be kept subject to public
inspection at all reasonable times. On or before February 1 each year, the
Commission shall make a report to the Mayor of its proceedings with a full
statement of its receipts, disbursements, and the progress of its work for the
preceding calendar year.
(‘67 Code, § 33.50(C)) (Ord. 7-1945, passed 8-7-45)
§ 32.020 MEETINGS; QUORUM.
   A majority of the members of the City Plan Commission shall constitute a
quorum but no action of the Commission shall be binding unless authorized by a
majority of the Commission at a regular or duly called special meeting thereof.
The Commission shall fix a time for holding regular meetings thereof, but a
special meeting may be called at any time by the President, or by two members
upon written request to the Secretary. Written notices shall be mailed by the
Secretary to all members at least two days before a special meeting, advising
them of the time and place of the meeting.
(‘67 Code, § 33.50(C)) (Ord. 7-1945, passed 8-7-45)
§ 32.021 APPROPRIATIONS FOR GENERAL EXPENSES.
   The Common Council shall appropriate from the general funds of the city for
the payment of the expenses of the City Plan Commission a sum of money
sufficient for the operation of the City Plan Commission annually. The sum of
money when so appropriated shall be included in the annual tax levy for general
expenses made by the Common Council.
(‘67 Code, § 33.50(D)) (Ord. 7-1945, passed 8-7-45)

DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION
§ 32.035 COMPOSITION.
   (A)   Under the provisions of I.C. 36-10-3-1 et seq., as amended, known and
hereby cited as the park and recreation law, there is hereby established a
Department of Parks and Recreation composed of the Board of Parks and
Recreation, a Park Superintendent, and any other personnel that the Board shall
determine.
   (B)   The Board shall be composed of five members. The Mayor shall select
four regular members based on their interest in and knowledge of parks and
recreation but not more than two of the regular members may be affiliated with
the same political party. The Board shall also include an ex officio member
from the North Lawrence School Corporation's Board of Trustees to be appointed
by the Board of Trustees.
(‘67 Code, § 33.51(A),(B)) (Ord. 12-1966, passed 5-16-66; Am. Ord. 1-1968,
passed 1-15-68; Am. Ord. 39-2004, passed 12-14-04)
§ 32.036 TERM OF OFFICE.
   Upon the establishment of a Board of Parks and Recreation, the terms of the
members initially appointed shall be one, two, three, and four years.
Thereafter as a term expires, each new appointment shall be for a four-year
term. All terms shall expire on the first Monday in January, but an appointee
shall continue in office until his successor is appointed.
(‘67 Code, § 33.51(C)) (Ord. 12-1966, passed 5-16-66; Am. Ord. 1-1968, passed
1-15-68)
§ 32.037 OFFICERS.
   At its first regular meeting in each year, the Board of Parks and Recreation
shall elect a President and a Vice- President. The Vice-President shall have
authority to act as the President of the Board during the absence or disability
of the President.
(‘67 Code, § 33.51(D)) (Ord. 12-1966, passed 5-16-66; Am. Ord. 1-1968, passed
1-15-68)
§ 32.038 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (A)   The Board of Parks and Recreation shall have the general power to
perform all acts necessary to acquire and develop sites and facilities to
conduct the programs that are generally understood to be park and recreation
functions, including all powers and duties provided by I.C. 36-10-3-1 et seq.,
and all laws amendatory thereof or supplemental thereto.
   (B)   The Board may create an advisory council and special committees
composed of citizens interested in the problem of parks and recreation in
accordance with the provisions of I.C. 36-10-3-1 et seq., and all laws
amendatory thereof or supplemental thereto.
(‘67 Code, § 33.51(E), (F)) (Ord. 12-1966, passed 5-16-66; Am. Ord. 1-1968,
passed 1-15-68)
§ 32.039 ANNUAL BUDGET REPORT.
   The Board of Parks and Recreation shall prepare and submit an annual budget
in the same manner as other departments of the city government. The Board may
accept gifts, donations, and subsidies for park and recreation purposes.
(‘67 Code, § 33.51(G)) (Ord. 12-1966, passed 5-16-66; Am. Ord. 1-1968, passed
1-15-68)
§ 32.040 NON-REVERTING CAPITAL FUND.
   (A)   Pursuant to the request of the City Park and Recreation Board, there
is hereby created a special non- reverting capital fund for the purpose of
creek bank beautification, well restoration, maintaining clubhouse heating and
cooling systems, carpet replacing, sank shop renovation, addition blacktopping,
supplementing the tree planting program, band shell restoration, irrigation
system maintenance, and general golf course improvements at Otis Park golf
course on a periodic basis.
      (1)   Monies collected at a rate to be determined from time to time by
the Park and Recreation Board from the surcharge or usage charge per round of
golf (9 or 18 holes) on green fees, and a surcharge or usage charge assigned to
memberships at Otis Park shall be deposited from time to time (but not less
than once each month) with the City Clerk-Treasurer who shall in turn deposit
the same in the said special non-revering capital fund.
      (2)   Monies so deposited in the said non- reverting capital fund shall
only be withdrawn and expended for the purposes herein set forth and only
pursuant to a prior appropriation ordinance having been adopted pursuant to law
by the Common Council.
(Ord. 5-1989, passed 2-14-89)
   (B)   Pursuant to the request of the City Park and Recreation Board, there
is hereby created a special non- reverting capital fund for the purpose of
improving and creating additional golf cart paths at Otis Park golf course on a
periodic basis.
      (1)   Monies collected at a rate to be determined from time to time by
the Park and Recreation Board from the increase costs of golf car rentals at
Otis Park shall be deposited from time to time (but not less than once each
month) with the City Clerk-Treasurer who shall in turn deposit the same in the
said special non-reverting capital fund.
      (2)   Monies so deposited in the said non- reverting capital fund shall
only be withdrawn and expended for the purposes herein set forth and only
pursuant to a prior appropriation ordinance having been adopted pursuant to law
by the Common Council.
(Ord. 7-1989, passed 2-14-89; Am. Ord. 5-1994, passed 1-11-94)
   (C)   Pursuant to the request of the City Park and Recreation Board, there
is hereby created a special non- reverting capital fund for the purpose of
maintenance problems, such as leaks in the pool, new pumps, maintenance of the
chlorination system, maintenance of the water slide, insurance on the slide,
and unexpected and unbudgeted costs of the John Lowery Municipal Pool on a
periodic basis.
      (1)   Slide fees and membership surcharge fees collected at rates
determined by the Park and Recreation Board for the use of the John Lowery
Municipal Pool shall be deposited from time to time (but not less than once
each month) with the City Clerk-Treasurer who shall in turn deposit the same in
the said special non-reverting capital fund.
      (2)   Monies so deposited in the said non- reverting capital fund shall
only be withdrawn and expended for the purposes herein set forth and only
pursuant to a prior appropriation ordinance having been adopted pursuant to law
by the Common Council.
   (D)   At the request of the City Park and Recreation Board, the special non-
reverting fund shall allow monies collected from aquatic programs sponsored by
the Park and Recreation Department and slide fees and membership surcharge fees
at rates determined by the Park and Recreation Board for the use of the John
Lowery Municipal Pool to be deposited from time to time (but not less than once
each month) with the City Clerk-Treasurer who shall in turn deposit the same in
the said special non-reverting fund.
   (E)   At the request of the City Park and Recreation Board, the special non-
reverting fund shall allow monies so deposited into the said non-reverting fund
be withdrawn and expended for sums owed to instructors of the aquatics programs
sponsored by the Park and Recreation Department and for the purpose of paying
maintenance expenses such as repairing leaks, purchasing new pumps, maintaining
the chlorination system, maintaining the water slide, insuring the slide, and
providing for other unexpected and unbudgeted costs at the John Lowery
Municipal Pool on a periodic basis as herein set forth and only pursuant to a
prior appropriation ordinance having been adopted pursuant to law by the Common
Council.
(Ord. 6-1989, passed 2-14-89; Am. Ord. 27-2008, passed 11-12-08; Am. Ord. 14-
2014, passed 9-9-14)

FIRE DEPARTMENT
§ 32.055 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   For provisions concerning the Fire Department, see §
71.001. For provisions concerning the personnel policies of the Fire
Department, see §
33.02.
§ 32.056 FIREFIGHTERS’ PENSION FUND.
   (A)   There is hereby created a Firefighters’ Pension Fund and a Board of
Trustees for the Firefighters’ Pension Fund in the city, as provided by I.C.
36-8-7-1 et seq., and all acts supplemental thereto and amendatory thereof.
   (B)   The Common Council hereby authorizes the Board of Trustees of the
Firefighters’ Pension Fund that the sum that shall be paid to permanently
disabled members and to the surviving spouses, children and parents of deceased
members is as follows:
      (1)   Upon retirement with disability during service, a member is
entitled to receive in monthly installments an amount equal to 55% of the
salary of a fully paid first class firefighter in the unit at the time of the
payment of the pension.
      (2)   If a member dies while in active service or after retirement:
         (a)   The surviving spouse is entitled to receive the following:
            1.    For the surviving spouse of a member who dies before January
1, 1989, 40% of the salary of a fully paid first class firefighter in the unit
at the time of the payment of the pension; and
            2.    For the surviving spouse of a member who dies after December
31, 1988, an amount per month, during the spouse’s life, equal to the greater
of 40% of the monthly pay of a first class firefighter or 55% of the monthly
benefit the deceased member was receiving or was entitled to receives on the
date of the member’s death; (these amounts shall be proportionately increased
or decreased if the salary of a first class firefighter is increased or
decreased); however, if the deceased member was not entitled to a benefit
because the member had not completed 20 years of service, for the purposes of
computing the second amount under this item, the member’s benefit shall be
considered to be 50% of the monthly salary of a first class firefighter in the
unit at the time of payment of the pension;
         (b)   The member’s children under 18 years of age are each entitled to
receive an amount equal to 15% of the salary of a fully paid first class
firefighter in the unit at the time of the payment of the pension; and
         (c)   Each parent of a deceased member who was eligible for a pension
is entitled to receive jointly an amount equal to 30% of the salary of a fully
paid first class firefighter in the unit at the time of the payment of the
pension.
      (3)   If a member dies in the line of duty after August 31, 1982, the
surviving spouse is entitled to an additional monthly benefit, during the
spouse’s lifetime, if the surviving spouse did not remarry before September 1,
1983, equal to the difference between the benefit to which the member would
have been entitled on the date of his death, but not less than 50% of the
monthly wage received by a fully paid first class firefighter and the amount
received by the spouse under division (2)(a). If the spouse remarried before
September 1, 1983, benefits ceased on the date of remarriage. The children of a
spouse receiving benefits under this division (3) may not receive more than a
total of 30% of the monthly wage received by a fully paid first class
firefighter. However, this limitation does not apply to the children of a
spouse receiving benefits under this division who are physically or mentally
disabled. For purposes of this division, "dies in the line of duty" means death
that occurs as a direct result of personal injury or illness incurred in the
member’s capacity as a firefighter while on the scene of an emergency run
(including false alarms) or on the way to or from the scene.
         (a)   If the local board finds upon the submission of satisfactory
proof that a child 18 years of age or older is mentally or physically
incapacitated and is not a ward of the state, the child is entitled to receive
the same amount as is paid to the surviving spouse of a deceased firefighter,
as long as the mental or physical incapacity continues. A sum paid for the
benefit of a child or children shall be paid to the remaining parent, if alive,
as long as the child or children reside with and are supported by the parent.
If the parent dies, the sum shall be paid to the lawful guardian of the child
or children.
         (b)   A member who has been in service 20 years, upon making a written
application to the Fire Chief, may be retired from all service with the
department with a medical examination or disability. The local board shall
authorize the payment to the retired member of 50% of the salary of a fully
paid first class firefighter of the unit at the time of the payment of the
pension, plus:
            1. For a member who retires before January 1, 1986, 2% of that
salary for each year of service over 20 years; or
            2. For a member who retires after December 31, 1985, 1% of that
salary for each six months of service over 20 years.
            3.   However, the pension in one year may not exceed an amount
greater than 74% of the salary of a fully paid first class firefighter. The
pension of the dependents of retired members is the same if the member dies
after retirement as it is for dependents of members who die in the service or
after retirement with disability.
         (c)   A member who is discharged from the Fire Department after having
served at least 20 years is entitled to receive the amount equal to the amount
that the member would have received if the member retired voluntarily. If a
member dies after retirement and leaves a surviving spouse or dependent child
or children, they are entitled to receive the amount provided for the
dependents of members who have died in the service of the Fire Department.
         (d)   All pensions in a class are on an equal basis. The local board
may not depart from this chapter in authorizing the payment of pensions.
         (e)   The monthly pension payable to a member or survivor may not be
reduced below the amount of the first full monthly pension received by that
person
      (4)   The Common Council authorizes the Board of Trustees of the
Firefighters’ Pension Fund to pay funeral benefits to the heirs or estates of
any active or retired member of the Fire Department who has suffered death from
any cause, after June 30, 2008, in an amount equal to the difference between
$12,000 and any lesser amount paid to such heirs or estates by the Public
Employees’ Retirement Fund of the state.
      (5)   All benefits paid hereunder shall be subject to § 401 of the
Internal Revenue Code.
   (C)   In each of the cases in division (B) above which provide for payment
to a dependent relative of a deceased firefighter, the Board of Trustees of the
Firefighters’ Pension Fund shall be the final judges of the question of
necessity and dependency and of the amounts within the limits of the law to be
paid in any case.
   (D)   The payments herein provided shall apply only with respect to the
widow, each dependent child, and heirs of any active or retired member of the
fire force who was hired and became a member of the Fire Department prior to
May 1, 1977. The provisions of this section shall not apply to widows,
dependent children, or heirs of any active or retired member of the Fire
Department who was or is hired and who became or becomes a member of the Fire
Department on or after May l, 1977.
   (E)   To the extent that the Board of Trustees of the Firefighters’ Pension
Fund may heretofore have paid since the effective date of I.C. 36-8-7-12, any
benefits or payments from the Firefighters’ Pension Fund to any widow or child
under the age of 18 years of any deceased member of the Fire Department in
excess of the minimum amount provided by law from time to time, the Common
Council hereby ratifies and approves retroactively all the excess payments so
made.
(‘67 Code, § 33.10) (Ord. 31-1939, passed 8-1-39; Am. Ord. 24-1977, passed 12-
13-77; Am. Ord. 32-1985, passed 11-12-85; Am. Ord. 10-1989, passed 2-14-89; Am.
Ord. 6-1990, passed 2-13-90; Am. Ord. 15-1992, passed 5-12-92; Am. Ord. 16-
1992, passed 5-12-92; Am. Ord. 22-2001, passed 7-24-01; Am. Ord. 19-2008,
passed 8-12-08)
Editor’s note:
   I.C. 36-8-7-12 was repealed by P.L. 196-1988, Sec. 5.
§ 32.057 FALSE ALARMS; FALSE CALLS.
   (A)   Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.
      FALSE FIRE ALARM. The activation of a fire alarm system resulting in a
response by the Fire Department when no fire or emergency condition exists,
including alarms triggered by malfunction, testing without prior notice, or
human error.
      FALSE FIRE CALL. A non-emergency call made to request Fire Department
services where no legitimate fire or emergency condition exists, including
intentional false reports.
      FIRE WATCH PERSONNEL. An individual(s) defined under 2014 Indiana Fire
Code 675 IAC 22-2.5.
      INTENTIONAL FALSE ALARM. The deliberate activation of a fire alarm or
call when no emergency exists.
   (B)   Fee schedule for false alarms and calls.
      (1)   False alarms/calls. Warnings with educational assistance will be
provided at the first occurrence(s). The Fire Chief or designee may impose a
fine of up to $500 at each occurrence thereafter.
      (2)   Intentional false alarms. Incidents deemed intentional may result
in a fine of up to $2,500 per incident and may lead to criminal prosecution
under state law.
      (3)   Exemptions. No penalty will be assessed if the false alarm or call
was caused by a system malfunction due to weather conditions, utility failure,
or other circumstances outside the responsible party’s control. All exemption
determinations shall be at the discretion of the Bedford Fire Department.
   (C)   Preventive requirements.
      (1)    The property owner, responsible party and/or alarm company must
notify the Bedford Police Department/Fire Department prior to any fire alarm
testing or maintenance that may result in false activation. If alarm testing or
repairs are performed without notifying the Bedford Police Department/Fire
Department, the property owner or alarm company may incur a $500 fine.
      (2)   In the event a required fire protection system is out of service or
has an excessive number of accidental activations that the Fire Chief or
designee determines the system to be defective, the property owner or
responsible party shall either evacuate the building or provide fire watch
personnel pursuant to 2014 Indiana Fire Code 675 IAC 22-2.5.
   (D)   Appeals process. Individuals or businesses may appeal assessed fines
within 30 days of the issuance.
(Ord. 20-2024, passed 12-17-24)
§ 32.058 INSPECTIONS; CODE COMPLIANCE.
   (A)   Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.
      INSPECTION. Any fire safety review conducted by the Fire Department,
including routine, requested, complaint-based inspections and any other
inspections specified by the Bedford Fire Department.
      VIOLATION. A failure to comply with applicable fire codes as determined
during an inspection.
   (B)   Inspection authority. The Fire Department is authorized to conduct
inspections as set forth above.
   (C)   Violations; penalties.
      (1)   Initial inspection. Violations identified in the initial inspection
must be corrected within 30 days. No fees or fines shall be assessed for the
initial inspection.
      (2)   Re-inspection and penalties.
         (a)   First re-inspection. If violations remain, a fine of $100 per
unresolved violation may be imposed.
         (b)   Second re-inspection. If violations persist, a fine of $250 per
unresolved violation may be imposed.
   (D)   Authority to temporarily close facilities. The Fire Chief of designee
may temporarily close any facility with severe violations that pose an
immediate risk, with the closure in effect until the facility achieves
compliance as determined by the Fire Chief or designee.
   (E)   Fee payment and inquiries. All fines shall be payable to the Clerk-
Treasurer’s Office, with payment details provided on citations. Questions may
be directed to the Fire Chief or designee.
   (F)   Amendment and adjustment. The schedule of fees and fines may be
adjusted by future ordinance or amendment.
(Ord. 21-2024, passed 12-17-24)
HOUSING AUTHORITY
§ 32.065 ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERS.
   (A)   Pursuant to I.C. 36-7-18-1 et seq., the Common Council upon due notice
having held a public hearing whereat an opportunity to be heard was granted to
all residents and taxpayers of the city and to all other interested persons,
having considered the testimony and evidence presented at said public hearing
and their own personal knowledge of dwelling accommodations and need for a
housing authority to function in the city, the Common Council hereby finds,
determines and declares, that: insanitary and unsafe inhabited dwelling
accommodations exist in the city; and there is a shortage of safe and sanitary
dwelling accommodations in the city available to persons of low income at
rentals they can afford; and there is a need for a housing authority to
function in the city.
   (B)   The City Housing Authority established above shall be composed of
seven members appointed by the Mayor, one of whom must be a resident of a
housing project under the jurisdiction of the Housing Authority and no more
than four of whom may be of the same political party, in accordance with I.C.
36-7-18-5.
