CHAPTER 101: OPEN BURNING
Section
   
101.01   Definitions
   
101.02   Prohibitions
   
101.03   Limited permits
   
101.04   Exemptions; variances
   
101.05   Emergencies
 
   
101.99   Penalty; enforcement
§ 101.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   OPEN BURNING. The burning of any materials wherein air contaminants
resulting from combustion are emitted directly into the air, without passing
through a stack or chimney from an enclosed chamber.
(Ord. 12-2010, passed 8-10-10)
§ 101.02 PROHIBITIONS.
   No person shall start, kindle, cause, allow, or maintain any form of open
burning of any materials on private or public property, except as specifically
authorized by this chapter. No person shall allow the accumulation or existence
of combustible material that constitutes or contributes to open burning.
(Ord. 12-2010, passed 8-10-10) Penalty, see §
101.99
§ 101.03 LIMITED PERMITS.
   The City of Bedford Fire Department may grant permits to land owners who are
developing one acre or more of real estate for either commercial purposes or
residential development. Said permits shall be limited in duration for a period
of time to be determined by the Fire Chief or his or her designated employee.
The cost of said permit shall be $100 for each 30-day period with a minimum
cost of $100. Permits may be obtained at the Bedford Fire Department between
the hours of 8 a.m. and 4 p.m. Monday through Friday.
(Ord. 12-2010, passed 8-10-10; Am. Ord. 2-2021, passed 2-16-21)
§ 101.04 EXEMPTIONS; VARIANCES.
   (A)   Exemptions. The following types of burning are allowed:
      (l)   The burning of charcoal, clean untreated wood, and other cooking
fuels customarily used in an outdoor grill, traditional food cooking devices,
or campfires.
         (a)   Campfires must be contained in a fire pit which is designed to
contain and control outdoor wood fires. Commercial fire pits must be used in
accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions. Fire pits must be placed on a
non-combustible surface at least twice the diameter of the fire pit.
         (b)   Fire pits must not exceed three feet in diameter. The fire may
not extend more than two feet above the fire pit. The fire pit must be
surrounded on the outside, above the ground, by a non-combustible material such
as, but not limited to, concrete block, bricks, or rocks.
         (c)   Burn barrels are prohibited.
      (2)   Fires used for recreational or ceremonial purposes such as school
pep rally fires or the celebration of scout activities. Recreational or
ceremonial fires shall meet the following conditions:
         (a)   Only clean untreated wood or charcoal shall be used. Paper
products can be used for ignition purposes only.
         (b)   The fire shall not be ignited more than two hours before the
recreational activity is to take place and shall be extinguished upon the
conclusion of the activity.
         (c)   The pile to be burned shall be less than 1000 cubic feet (for
example: 10 ft. × 10 ft. × 10 ft.).
         (d)   The local fire department shall be notified 24 hours in advance
if the pile to be burned is more than 125 cubic feet (for example: 5 ft. × 5
ft. × 5 ft.).
         (e)   The fire shall not be used for disposing of refuse.
            1.   If said property is one acre or more, tree limbs, leaves and
grass clippings may be burned with approved permit from the City of Bedford
Fire Department.
            2.   Property owner may only burn tree limbs, leaves and grass
clippings from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. Property owner must notify City of Bedford Fire
Department of burn at least 24 hours in advance.
   (B)   Variances. Other types of fires may be approved as follows:
      (1)   A person may obtain a variance from the provisions of this chapter
by submitting a petition to the Bedford Board of Zoning. A person must submit
said petition to the Fire Chief in writing on a proscribed form which can be
obtained from the City of Bedford Fire Department. The Fire Chief or his
designated employee shall review said petition and make a recommendation to the
Board of Zoning at a special or regular public meeting. The Board of Zoning
shall review the petition and recommendation from the Fire Chief or his
designee and either grant or deny the petition for variance at the first
meeting following the date the petition is submitted to the Board of Zoning by
the Fire Chief.
      (2)   The City of Bedford Fire Department may place restrictions on said
variance in addition to the conditions set forth below as it may deem
appropriate; however, the Fire Chief or his designated employee shall not grant
a variance for burning that would otherwise violate the provisions of the 326
I.A.C. 4-1 et seq., as amended, and I.C. 13-17-9.
   (C)   Conditions on exemptions and variances. The following conditions apply
to all exemptions and variances:
      (1)   Burning shall be done during safe weather conditions. Burning shall
not occur during high winds, temperature inversions, air stagnation, or when a
pollution alert or ozone action day has been declared.
      (2)   Fires must be attended at all times until completely extinguished.
      (3)   Fires must be extinguished if they create a fire hazard, nuisance,
pollution problem, or threat to public health as determined by enforcing
agency.
      (4)   The property owner shall have firefighting equipment adequate for
the size of the fire on-site and nearby during times of burning.
      (5)   Burning shall not be for disposal of garbage, refuse (unless it
complies with division (A)(2)(e)1. or trash as defined in §
94.01 of the Bedford City Code).
      (6)   All burning shall comply with other federal, state, and local laws,
rules and ordinances.
(Ord. 12-2010, passed 8-10-10; Am. Ord. 2-2021, passed 2-16-21) Penalty, see §
101.99
§ 101.05 EMERGENCIES.
   The Mayor may allow emergency burning of petroleum products, high
explosives, or other dangerous materials where such fires are properly
controlled by a responsible person and are deemed necessary in the public
interest. The Mayor may also allow open burning of refuse consisting of
material resulting from a disaster if the Mayor has declared such a disaster in
the area.
(Ord. 12-2010, passed 8-10-10)
§ 101.99 PENALTY; ENFORCEMENT.
   (A)   Any person found in violation of this chapter shall be subject to the
following procedures:
      (1)   Any fire, law enforcement officer or planning personnel of the city
may enter upon property located within the city boundaries for the purpose of
investigating a violation of this chapter and may order a person to correct the
violation by immediately extinguishing the fire.
      (2)   A person who violates this chapter shall be fined in an amount not
to exceed $2,500.
      (3)   Failure or refusal by the violator to immediately extinguish the
fire in violation of this chapter shall also result in the Fire Department
having the authority to go upon private property to extinguish said fire.
      (4)   Each subsequent starting, kindling, causing, or allowing of a new
fire after a warning notice or citation has been issued shall be considered a
separate offense.
      (5)   Liability for fire: Any person who allows the accumulation or
existence of combustible material which constitutes or contributes to open
burning may not refute liability for violation of this chapter on the basis
that said fire was set by vandals, an accident, or an act of God.
   (B)   The open burning provisions are enforceable by the duly appointed
fire, police, or planning personnel within the city, acting on his/her own
initiative or at the request of the Mayor.
(Ord. 12-2010, passed 8-10-10)

unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.

of the public in return for a valuable consideration.
   (B)   All pool rooms in the city shall be closed and the entrances thereto
locked between the hours of 12:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., official city time, of

   (B)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall issue the license required by division (A)
to any person making application therefor, who is otherwise legally entitled to
operate a roller skating rink within the city, for a term of one year from the
date of issuance thereof, upon payment by that person, firm, or corporation of
a license fee of $50.
   (C)   No person engaged in the operation of a roller skating rink within the
city shall permit the roller skating rink to be open for business or to be used
for roller skating between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. official city
time. However, no skating rink shall be opened for business on Sunday earlier
than 1:00 p.m.
(‘67 Code, § 110.01) (Ord. 9-l953, passed 5-5-53)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 111.01 COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   No person shall peddle or solicit without having complied with the
provisions of this chapter.
(‘67 Code, § 111.03) (Ord. l9-l967, passed 8-28-67)
Penalty, see § 111.99
§ 111.02 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   FIXED PLACE OF BUSINESS. A business operated and conducted from the same
location, for a period of at least 20 continuous days in the city.
   PEDDLE. To sell and make immediate delivery, or offer for sale and immediate
delivery, at any place within the city other than from a fixed place of
business, any goods, wares or merchandise, in possession of the seller.
   PEDDLER. Any person who peddles, as defined above.
   SOLICIT. To sell or take orders, or offer to sell or take orders, at any
place within the city other than at a fixed place of business, for goods,
wares, or merchandise for future delivery; for services to be performed; or for
magazines or publications other than newspapers for future delivery.
   SOLICITOR. Any person who solicits, as defined above.
(‘67 Code, § 111.01)
§ 111.03 UNLICENSED OR UNINVITED PEDDLERS A NUISANCE.
   (A)   The practice of going in and upon residential property, or ringing a
doorbell or knocking on a door of a private residence, including an apartment,
in the city, by any solicitor or peddler not having been requested or invited
to do so by the owner or owners, occupant or occupants, or lessee, of the
private residence or apartments, for the purpose of soliciting or peddling, is
declared to be a nuisance.
   (B)   Any peddler or solicitor, being uninvited, who goes on or upon
residential property in the city, without a license as provided by §§
111.10 through
111.15, shall be deemed to have committed a nuisance, unless the entry shall be
exempted from the operation of this chapter.
(‘67 Code, § 111.02) (Ord. l9-1967, passed 8-28-67)
Penalty, see § 111.99
§ 111.04 EXCEPTIONS.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the following persons.
   (A)   Any person soliciting or peddling anything which that person has
personally manufactured or produced. This exemption shall apply only to natural
persons.
   (B)   Any farmer, poultryman, or horticulturist soliciting or peddling his
own produce. This exemption shall apply only to natural persons and shall not
apply to farmers, poultrymen, or horticulturists who buy goods for resale, as
well as selling their own produce.
   (C)   Any natural person soliciting or peddling for, or selling tickets for
any approved religious, charitable, school, educational, veteran’s, or civic
organization.
   (D)   Fraternal organizations having established local chapters.
   (E)   Peddling or soliciting newspapers, ice, milk, cream, butter, eggs,
cheese, laundry, baked goods, dry cleaning, or dairy products.
   (F)   Salesmen or agents for wholesale houses or firms who solicit orders
from, or sell to retail dealers for resale, manufacturers for manufacturing
purposes, or bidders for public works or supplies.
(‘67 Code, § 111.13) (Ord. l9-1967, passed 8-28-67)
LICENSES AND PERMITS
§ 111.10 APPLICATION.
   (A)   Licenses shall be issued by the Bedford Police Department, upon the
applicant’s complying with the following provisions.
      (1)   Giving his name, present address, and his permanent address.
      (2)   Giving a brief description of the nature of the business and the
kinds of goods, property, services, or publication to be peddled or solicited.
      (3)   Paying the license fee required by §
111.12 for the license.
      (4)   Giving the name and address of the licensed employer and exhibiting
credentials showing he is an authorized employee or representative of the
licensed employer, in the event the application is for an employee’s license.
      (5)   Furnishing two full-face photographs of the applicant, two inches
by two inches in size, one of which shall be attached at all times to the
license, and the other delivered by the Clerk-Treasurer to the Chief of Police
for his files.
      (6)   Stating that he has not been convicted of committing any felony or
crime involving moral turpitude.
   (B)   All information required by divisions (A)(1),(2),(4), and (6) above
shall be set forth in a verified written application which shall be subscribed
and sworn to by the applicant before an officer duly authorized by law to
administer oaths.
(‘67 Code, § 111.04) (Ord. 19-1967, passed 8-28-67; Am. Ord. 16-1988, passed 7-
12-88)
§ 111.11 REGISTRATION WITH POLICE DEPARTMENT.
   (A)   Every person who desires to peddle or solicit shall register in a
registration book provided for that purpose in the Police Department, his name
and address; the name and address of the person who he represents, if any; the
names and addresses of at least two references as to his moral character,
honesty, and integrity; a brief description of the nature of the business in
which he is engaged; and the kind of goods, property, services, or publications
to be peddled or solicited. The person shall also furnish his fingerprints and
thumbprints, to be taken by the Police Department.
   (B)   No person shall be registered and no permit shall be issued except
upon a person exhibiting a valid license for peddling or soliciting, or a
clearance from the license collector stating that no license is required.
   (C)   The registration shall be valid for a period of one year and the
person must register at the end of each one-year period.
   (D)   As evidence of compliance with the provisions of this section, the
Police Department shall issue to each person who complies with this chapter a
permit which shall show the name and address of the person; the name of the
person he represents or by whom he is employed, if any; and the kind of goods,
property, services, or publications to be peddled or solicited.
(‘67 Code, § 111.05) (Ord. 19-1967, passed 8-28-67)
§ 111.12 LICENSE FEES.
   (A)   Every person desiring a solicitor’s or peddler’s license shall pay to
the city a license fee of $100 per year, payable in advance.
   (B)   Any natural person having a valid solicitor’s or peddler’s license and
who actually peddles or solicits himself, shall have licenses issued to his
employees in accordance with division (C) below.
   (C)   Each employee of any licensed solicitor or peddler shall pay to the
city a license fee of $25 per year, payable in advance.
(‘67 Code, § 111.06)
   (D)   Conviction and punishment of any person for peddling or soliciting
without a license shall not excuse or exempt that person from the payment of
any license fee due or unpaid at the time of conviction. Nothing in this
chapter shall prevent criminal prosecution for any violation of any provision
of this chapter.
(‘67 Code,§ 111.l5)
(Ord. l9-l967, passed 8-28-67)
Penalty, see § 111.99
§ 111.13 DISPLAY OF LICENSE.
   (A)   Every solicitor or peddler at all times while engaged in peddling or
soliciting shall wear and display the license issued to him under the
provisions of §
111.11.
(‘67 Code, § 111.08)
   (B)   Every solicitor or peddler licensed under this chapter shall have his
photograph attached to his license and shall have his license in his immediate
possession at all times. When peddling or soliciting he shall display the
license upon demand by any police officer of the city and upon demand of any
person to whom he is peddling or soliciting.
(‘67 Code,§ 111.07)
(Ord. 19-1967, passed 8-28-67)
Penalty, see § 111.99
§ 111.14 TRANSFER.
   (A)   Licenses and permits issued pursuant to this chapter shall not be
assigned or transferred, nor shall they, or either of them, be used by any
person other than the person to whom they were issued, except as herein
provided.
   (B)   No person shall transfer, loan, or permit the use of his license or
permit by any other person, except as herein provided.
   (C)   Where a person who is not himself soliciting or peddling, has taken
out licenses for bona-fide employees, and the licenses are issued in the names
of the employer and the employee, the license may be transferred subject to the
following conditions.
      (l)   The license and the permit must be presented to the Clerk-
Treasurer.
      (2)   The permit is to be retained by the Clerk- Treasurer.
      (3)   A notation must be made upon the license to indicate its transfer
from one employee to another.
      (4)   The new employee must comply with the provisions of §
111.11.
      (5)   The transfer may be made upon the payment of a transfer fee of $15.
(‘67 Code, § 111.12) (Ord. 19-1967, passed 8-28-67)
Penalty, see § 111.99
§ 111.15 REVOCATION.
   (A)   Licenses issued pursuant to this chapter may be revoked by the Mayor
after notice and hearing, for any of the following causes.
      (l)   Fraud, misrepresentation, or any false statement contained in the
application for a license.
      (2)   Fraud, misrepresentation, or any false statement made to the Police
Department in furnishing the information required by §
111.11.
      (3)   Any violation of the provisions of this chapter.
      (4)   Conviction of the licensee of any felony or crime involving moral
turpitude.
      (5)   Conducting the soliciting or peddling in an unlawful manner or in a
manner so as to constitute a breach of the peace or to be a menace to the
health, safety, or general welfare of the people of the city.
      (6)   Conducting the soliciting or peddling by motor-bicycles, bicycles,
scooters, or motorcycles.
   (B)   Notice of the hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in
writing stating the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the
hearing. This notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee at the
address given on the application for the license, at least ten days prior to
the date set for the hearing.
   (C)   Any person aggrieved by the decision of the Mayor shall have the right
to appeal to the Board of Public Works and Safety. This appeal shall be taken
by filing with the Clerk-Treasurer a written statement of the grounds for the
appeal within l4 days after notice of the decision by the Mayor has been given.
The Board of Public Works and Safety shall set the time and place for hearing
the appeal, and notice of the time and place shall be given by the Clerk-
Treasurer in the manner provided in division (B) above for notice of a hearing
for a license revocation by the Mayor.
(‘67 Code, § 111.14) (Ord. 19-1967, passed 8-28-67)
Penalty, see § 111.99
PROHIBITED ACTS
§ 111.20 RESTRICTED HOURS AND AREAS.
   (A)   No person shall peddle or solicit on Sunday, nor before the hour of 8:
00 a.m. or after the hour of 6:00 p.m. of any day, except in response to the
prior request or invitation to do so made by the person to whom the peddler or
solicitor is peddling or soliciting.
(‘67 Code,§ 111.09)
   (B)   No person shall peddle or solicit in or from any vehicle while parked
or stopped in any metered parking area, unloading zone, or other area where
parking is prohibited, or on any sidewalk adjacent thereto, in the city.
(‘67 Code, § 111.16)
(Ord. 19-1967, passed 8-28-67)
Penalty, see § 111.99
§ 111.21 OBEDIENCE TO SIGNS.
   No peddler or solicitor, or any person pretending to be a peddler or
solicitor, for the purpose of peddling or soliciting or pretending, shall
peddle or solicit or ring the bell or knock at any building whereon there is
painted, affixed, or otherwise displayed to public view on the premises any
sign containing any or all of the following words: “No Peddlers,” “No
Solicitors,” or “No Agents,” or which otherwise purports to prohibit peddling
or soliciting on the premises.
(‘67 Code, § 111.10) (Ord. 19-1967, passed 8-28-67)
Penalty, see § 111.99
§ 111.22 MISREPRESENTATION OF IDENTITY.
   No peddler or solicitor shall represent by words, writing, or action that he
is some other peddler or solicitor; that he is a partner, employee, or agent of
any peddler or solicitor when in fact he is not the partner, agent, or employee
of that peddler or solicitor; or that he is the employee, representative,
agent, or partner of any person when in fact he is not the employee,
representative, agent, or partner of that person.
(‘67 Code, § 111.11) (Ord. 19-1967, passed 8-28-67)
Penalty, see § 111.99
PAWNBROKERS
§ 111.30 COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   No person shall engage in the business of pawnbroking without complying with
the requirements of this subchapter.
(‘67 Code, § 113.01) (Ord. 75, passed 8-4-1896)
Penalty, see § 111.99
§ 111.31 LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE.
   The pawnbroker shall obtain from the Clerk-Treasurer a license to carry on
his business. It is hereby made the duty of the Clerk-Treasurer to issue the
license for a year upon receipt of $l00.
(‘67 Code, § 113.01) (Ord. 75, passed 8-4-1896)
Penalty, see § 111.99
§ 111.32 RECORDS TO BE KEPT.
   (A)   The pawnbroker shall keep a record of all goods or property pledged to
him, upon which he shall loan any money or which he may purchase, stating the
name of the person who deposited the pawn or sold the goods and property; his
residence and age; and the probable value, name, and description of the
article. This record shall be kept in a book used exclusively for this purpose.
   (B)   Every licensee shall, during ordinary hours of business upon demand,
exhibit to any police officer of the city, the book and entries required by
division (A) above, and upon demand shall also exhibit to the inspection of a
policeman or other officer of the city, any goods or property left with the
pawnbroker.
(‘67 Code, § 113.01) (Ord. 75, passed 8-4-1896)
Penalty, see § 111.99
§ 111.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter for which
another penalty is not provided shall be fined not more than $2500 for each
offense.
(‘67 Code, § l.09)
   (B)   Any person violating any provision of §§
111.0l through
111.22 shall be fined not less than $50 and not more than $300. Every day upon
which any violation shall occur or upon which any violation shall continue,
shall constitute a separate offense.
(‘67 Code, § 111.99) (Ord. 19-1967, passed 8-28-67)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 112.01 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this chapter the following definition shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   TAXICAB. Every motor-driven vehicle used within the city for public hire and
carrying passengers for hire or furnishing for use, passenger transportation
for hire or otherwise, along or over public streets in the city, the
destination or route of which is under the direction of a passenger transported
therein.
(Ord. 14-2004, passed 5-11-04)
§ 112.02 COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   No person shall drive, stand or park any taxicab upon any street in the city
except in accordance with the regulations, terms and conditions established by
this chapter.
(Ord. 14-2004, passed 5-11-04) Penalty, see §
112.99
LICENSE
§ 112.10 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall operate a taxicab service upon any street in the city
without having a valid license to do so in full force and effect.
(Ord. 14-2004, passed 5-11-04) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.11 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE FOR TAXICAB SERVICE.
   Any person desiring to operate a taxicab service shall, before undertaking
to do so, file with the Bedford Police Department a written, signed application
for a license, sworn to by the applicant. This application shall show the
following information.
   (A)   The name of the person, partnership, firm or corporation desiring the
license. If a firm, the full names of each of the partners thereof.
   (B)   The place of residence and principal place of business of the
applicant.
   (C)   A statement that the applicant intends to and will, if issued a
license to do so, operate the taxicabs as shall be necessary in that service;
and that he or she owns and is the sole owner of the described taxicabs and
intends to and will operate the taxicabs in that service 24 hours each day.
   (D)   The age, sex, and the residence of each person who will drive a
taxicab for the applicant.
   (E)   The make, model and serial number of each vehicle for which a license
is applied.
   (F)   The location and address of the office of the applicant.
   (G)   In addition to providing an application properly executed, each
applicant for a taxicab license shall present a certificate of inspection, to
be provided by the Bedford Police Department, certifying that each of the
applicant’s vehicles to be operated as a taxicab was inspected by the Police
Department and found to meet the following requirements:
      (1)   It is in a good state of mechanical repair;
      (2)   It is equipped with safe tires;
      (3)   It is equipped with any additional necessary safety devices such as
hand brakes, rearview mirror, turn signals, safety glass, horns and the like;
      (4)   It is in a clean and sanitary condition;
      (5)   The seats and interior are in a good state of repair so as not to
cause injury or damage to any passenger or his or her property;
      (6)   It is equipped with two-way radio communication system in good
operating condition or has an operating cellular phone on board;
      (7)   It is clearly identified on the vehicle’s exterior that it is a
taxicab and the markings must be of reflective material and must be clearly
visible from the front, rear, left and right sides of the vehicle; and
      (8)   The exterior of none of the vehicles is painted entirely red.
(Ord. 14-2004, passed 5-11-04) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.12 LIABILITY INSURANCE.
   No license shall be issued and no taxicab shall be operated upon any street
in the city until there has been filed with the Bedford Police Department and
the Clerk- Treasurer an indemnity undertaking or policy of insurance executed
by an insurance company authorized to execute these instruments in the state.
The insurance shall run for the year of the license to be issued to the
applicant, all subject to approval of the Bedford Police Department and the
Clerk-Treasurer. The insurance shall provide for the payment of any final
judgment that may be rendered against the insured for damages to property or
for bodily injury or death of passengers or other persons resulting from a
collision or other accident for which the person may be found liable while
operating the taxicab described in the application. The insurance shall be a
minimum of $100,000 for property damage and $250,000 for the injury or death of
any person or persons so injured or killed as above provided. The insurance
company shall hold the City of Bedford harmless.
(Ord. 14-2004, passed 5-11-04) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.13 LICENSE FEES FOR VEHICLES.
   The applicant, on presentation of his or her application and certificate of
inspection, shall purchase a license for each taxicab covered by the
application from the Bedford Police Department. The annual license fee for each
taxicab for the calendar year shall be $25.00. Application for renewal of the
license shall be made each year in the month of December for the ensuing year.
The fee for a license applied for between January l and July l of the current
calendar year shall be that portion of $25.00 which is proportional to the
unexpired portion of the current calendar year, and l5 days or more shall count
as one full month. On or after July l of the current calendar year, the license
fee for each taxicab for the remainder of the year shall be $12.50. The license
shall not be sold or assigned by the holder except with the prior consent and
approval of the Board of Public Works and Safety.
(Ord. 14-2004, passed 5-11-04) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.14 ISSUANCE AND DISPLAY OF LICENSE PLATES.
   The Bedford Police Department shall issue to the applicant separately
numbered license plates for each vehicle covered by the application. Each
license plate shall be securely attached to and displayed on the exterior front
of the vehicle for which it was issued at the point customarily used for
displaying license plates.
(Ord. 14-2004, passed 5-11-04) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.15 PERMANENT OFFICE REQUIRED.
   No license shall be granted to any person to operate any taxicab unless the
person has a permanent office from which to control and regulate the operation
of his or her taxicabs.
(Ord. 14-2004, passed 5-11-04) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.16 ADDITIONAL VEHICLES.
   (A)   No additional vehicle shall be added to or used by the holder of any
license until he or she shall have reported the addition to the Bedford Police
Department, made application for a license for the additional vehicle, and
received a separately numbered license plate for the additional equipment. The
application for additional equipment shall be made upon the same forms and
there shall be furnished the same information provided for in the original
application for a license.
   (B)   In the event of an emergency wherein extra taxicabs would be necessary
for the transportation of passengers, and subject to the approval of the
Bedford Police Department, temporary operating permits, good for seven days
from and including the date of issuance, may be issued to the applicant upon
the proper application for and upon the payment at the time of the application
of a fee of $5 for each temporary operating permit. This shall apply only to
taxicab operators having previously secured the regular city license for the
operation of a taxicab service, provided each vehicle had been issued a
certificate of inspection.
   (C)   In the event of any disaster or emergency such as a flood, riot, war,
evacuation, or any catastrophe, the Bedford Police Department shall have the
right to suspend the foregoing requirements for temporary operating permits
during the emergency.
(Ord. 14-2004, passed 5-11-04) Penalty, see §
112.99
TAXICAB DRIVER’S LICENSE
§ 112.25 DRIVER’S LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall drive a taxicab within the city without first having secured
a license to do so from the city, which license shall be in full force and
effect. The license shall be prominently displayed in the taxicab so that it
can be readily seen and read by all passengers carried by the driver. The
annual license fee for a taxicab driver’s license for the calendar year shall
be $5.
(Ord. 14-2004, passed 5-11-04) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.26 APPLICATION FOR DRIVER’S LICENSE.
   Every person desiring to drive a taxicab in the city shall, before
undertaking to do so, file with the Bedford Police Department an application in
writing for a taxicab driver’s license, sworn to by the applicant, which
application shall show the following.
   (A)   The name and address of the applicant;
   (B)   The address of each place of residence of the applicant during the
three years prior to the date of the application;
   (C)   The place of employment, the kind of employment, and the name of each
employer of the applicant for the two years immediately preceding the date of
the application;
   (D)   The age and sex of the applicant;
   (E)   The applicant’s experience in general motor vehicle operation;
   (F)   Whether or not the applicant has ever been convicted in any court of
any crime or misdemeanor, and if so, the facts concerning each conviction;
   (G)   Whether or not the applicant uses intoxicating liquors or beverages;
   (H)   A photocopy of the applicant’s state public passenger chauffeur
license;
   (I)   Upon the face of the application, a certificate of the Chief of Police
that the applicant has been examined as to his or her ability to drive a motor
vehicle under the traffic code of the city and the traffic laws of the state; a
statement as to the conviction of any crime or misdemeanor; and a statement
that, in the opinion of the officer, the applicant is a fit and proper person
to receive a taxicab driver’s license; and
   (J)   A certified copy of the applicant’s driving record obtained by the
applicant from the Indiana Bureau of Motor Vehicles.
(Ord. 14-2004, passed 5-11-04) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.27 ISSUANCE.
   (A)   Prior to the filing of an application for a taxicab driver’s license
with the Bedford Police Department, the Bedford Police Department shall
photograph and take the fingerprints of the applicant and keep the photograph
and fingerprints as part of the permanent records of the Bedford Police
Department. Upon receipt of the application for a taxicab driver’s license
properly approved by the Chief of Police and accompanied by the applicant’s
remittance of the license fee, the Bedford Police Department shall issue to the
applicant a taxicab driver’s license which shall show the following:
      (1)   The name and address of the applicant;
      (2)   The license number;
      (3)   The expiration date and/or duration of the license; and
      (4)   The right thumb print and a small, full face photograph of the
applicant, the size of which shall be determined by the Bedford Police
Department.
   (B)   The Bedford Police Department may, at its discretion, issue in lieu of
the regular license, a temporary permit authorizing the applicant to drive a
taxicab for a period of not more than ten days, at the end of which time the
regular license shall be granted and issued to the applicant or the application
therefore shall be denied.
(Ord. 14-2004, passed 5-11-04) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.28 FALSE STATEMENTS.
   Any taxicab driver’s license shall be revoked if the license was obtained by
false statement, either voluntarily or involuntarily made in an application,
and in addition, the driver may be punished as provided in §
112.99.
(Ord. 14-2004, passed 5-11-04) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.29 LIQUOR VIOLATIONS.
   If any person holding a license under this chapter is convicted of violating
any provision of the liquor laws of the state, the license so held shall be
revoked and that person shall not be granted a new license within three years
of the date of the revocation.
(Ord. 14-2004, passed 5-11-04) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.30 REVOCATION.
   (A)   Any license issued to any operator of a taxicab business or any driver
may be revoked or indefinitely suspended by the appropriate court, if the
following provisions are met:
      (1)   Any provision of this chapter is violated by any license holder,
whether operator or driver.
      (2)   There is repeated or flagrant violation of any ordinance of the
city or laws of the state regulating or controlling traffic upon the streets of
the city.
      (3)   Upon report of the Chief of Police it appears to the satisfaction
of the appropriate court that the vehicle so licensed is not properly
constructed, is not in good mechanical repair and condition, or is not a safe
conveyance for the transportation of passengers.
      (4)   Upon it being shown to the satisfaction of the appropriate court
that any representation made by the licensee in the application for the license
is false.
   (B)   Notice of the hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in
writing stating the grounds of the complaint, and the time and place of the
hearing. This notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee at the
address given on the application for the license, at least ten days prior to
the date set forth the hearing.
   (C)   Any person aggrieved by the decision of the court shall have the right
to appeal. This appeal shall be taken by filing a written statement of the
grounds for the appeal after notice of the decision by the court has been
given. The time and place for hearing the appeal shall be set, and notice of
the time and place shall be given in the manner provided in division (B) above
for notice of a hearing for a license revocation.
(Ord. 14-2004, passed 5-11-04) Penalty, see §
112.99
DRIVER REGULATIONS
§ 112.40 SOLICITING FARES.
   (A)   The driver of any taxicab shall not in any manner obstruct or impede
traffic in any of the streets, alleys, or public places in the city. However,
the driver of a taxicab may solicit employment by driving through any street or
public place without stopping, at such speed and in such manner as not to
interfere with or impede traffic.
   (B)   No taxicab driver shall solicit passengers for a public taxicab upon
the streets and public places in the city by outcry or blowing of a horn except
that at a railroad station the operator may solicit by word of mouth while
within ten feet of his cab.
(Ord. 14-2004, passed 5-11-04) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.41 INTOXICATION PROHIBITED.
   No person shall drive a taxicab while intoxicated, or indulging in or having
indulged in intoxicating liquor or beverage. No operator of a taxicab business
shall permit any person who is intoxicated, who has been drinking intoxicating
liquor or beverage, or who has the smell or odor of intoxicating liquor or
beverage upon his or her breath, to drive a taxicab.
(Ord. 14-2004, passed 5-11-04) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.42 LOST ARTICLES.
   It shall be the duty of every person operating a taxicab business to
promptly notify the Police Department of any article found in any vehicle
operated by him or her, and a description thereof, and where it is kept and may
be found, so it may be returned to the owner.
(Ord. 14-2004, passed 5-11-04) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.43 INFORMATION TO PASSENGERS.
   Every driver of a taxicab upon being requested to do so by any person who
is, or has been, or is about to become, a passenger in the vehicle shall give
to that person his or her name, taxicab driver’s license number, state public
passenger chauffeur license number and the license number of the vehicle.
(Ord. 14-2004, passed 5-11-04) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.44 BAGGAGE.
   Every passenger in any taxicab shall be allowed to have conveyed with him or
her in the vehicle, without charge therefor, his or her ordinary light
traveling baggage in an amount not to exceed 100 pounds in weight.
(Ord. 14-2004, passed 5-11-04) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.45 RATE CARD TO BE POSTED.
   The operator of a taxicab business shall have printed on a card the maximum
fare and rate for transportation of passengers, together with the prevailing
schedule of rates for the taxicab. This card shall be prominently displayed in
each taxicab so that it can readily be seen and read by all passengers.
(Ord. 14-2004, passed 5-11-04) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.46 TAXICABS TO BE KEPT CLEAN.
   Every taxicab shall be kept in as good state of repair and in as clean and
sanitary a condition as on the date of the issuance of its certificate of
inspection. The Traffic Division of the Police Department shall inspect each
vehicle licensed as a taxicab at least one time in each calendar quarter of
each calendar year. The Traffic Division of the Police Department may make
additional and separate inspections of any licensed vehicle at any time during
the term of the license. If a taxicab is not in a good state of repair or is
not being maintained in a clean and sanitary condition, the Inspector may order
the operator to remove the vehicle from service until the conditions are
corrected. In the event that the vehicle is not immediately removed from
service, the Chief of Police shall file a complaint with the appropriate court
for the revocation or suspension of the license of the operator of the taxicab
business.
(Ord. 14-2004, passed 5-11-04) Penalty, see §
112.99
PASSENGER REGULATIONS
§ 112.55 PASSENGER VIOLATION.
   Any passenger in a taxicab who violates any state law or city ordinance may
be ejected from the vehicle by the driver thereof. If the passenger has paid
his or her fare in advance the driver shall return to him or her the unearned
balance of the fare.
(Ord. 14-2004, passed 5-11-04) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.56 REFUSAL TO PAY FARE.
   No person who employs any taxicab and who has been conveyed therein shall
refuse to pay for his or her passage. Whoever, with intent to defraud the owner
or driver of any public vehicle, engages carriage therein, shall be fined as
provided in §
112.99. Refusal to pay the lawful charge for his or her carriage or absconding
without payment or offer to pay, shall be evidence of the intent to defraud.
(Ord. 04-2004, passed 5-11-04) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.99 PENALTY.
   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter for which another
penalty is not provided shall be fined not less than $50 and not more than
$200, and court costs as provided by law.
(Ord. 14-2004, passed 5-11-04)
CHAPTER 113: ADVERTISING
Section
   
113.01   Advertising policy for city buses
§ 113.01 ADVERTISING POLICY FOR CITY BUSES.
   (A)   The Department of Transportation is authorized to adopt an advertising
policy to regulate the use of advertising space on the interior and exterior of
city buses.
   (B)   The Department is specifically authorized to fix advertisement rates;
determine the size and suitability of advertising material; and promulgate such
other rules and regulations governing the display of advertising materials in
and on city buses as the authority may from time to time deem appropriate.
(Ord. 17-1983, passed 7-12-83)
CHAPTER 114: CABLE TELEVISION
Section
   
114.01   FCC rate regulations
   
114.02   Time for consideration
   
114.03   Certification forms
§ 114.01 FCC RATE REGULATIONS.
   The city will follow the FCC Rate Regulations in its regulation of the Basic
Service Rates and Charges of the company and any other cable television system
operating in the city, notwithstanding any different or inconsistent provisions
in the franchise.
(Ord. 29-1993, passed 11-9-93)
§ 114.02 TIME FOR CONSIDERATION.
   In connection with such regulation, the city will ensure a reasonable
opportunity for consideration of the views of interested parties.
(Ord. 29-1993, passed 11-9-93)
§ 114.03 CERTIFICATION FORMS.
   The Mayor, or his or her designee, is authorized to execute on behalf of the
city and file with the FCC such certification forms or other instruments as are
now or may hereafter be required by the FCC Rate Regulations in order to enable
the city to regulate Basic Service Rates and Charges.
(Ord. 29-1993, passed 11-9-93)
TITLE XIII: GENERAL OFFENSES
Chapter
   
130.   OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY
   
131.   OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC ORDER
CHAPTER 130: OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY
Section
   
130.01   Defacing public property
   
130.02   Reward for information concerning safety devices
§ 130.01 DEFACING PUBLIC PROPERTY.
   (A)   No person shall ride or drive over, across, or upon any park or park
property of the city, or any grass plat or tree plat in the streets of the
city; or lounge, sit, lie, stand, or congregate upon the grass plat of the park
on the west side of the public square of the city, known as Lawrence Park.
   (B)   No person shall ride or drive any animal or vehicle against or upon
any lamp post in the city; or scratch, chip, break, mutilate, or otherwise
damage or deface any of the light posts; or post any bill, poster,
advertisement, notice, or placard upon or against any of the lamp posts; or
stain, paint, write upon, or otherwise disfigure any of the lamp posts.
(Ord. 25, passed 8-20-12)
   (C)   No person shall make, paint, post, or in any way affix to or upon any
curbstone, flagging, cross walk, pavement, guardstone, monument, fountain,
step, fire plug, lamp post, or to or upon any telegraph, telephone, fire alarm,
electric light, or power pole within the city, any sign, bill, notice,
announcement, or other advertising medium. This division shall not apply to any
notice or announcement required to be made or given by any officer under any
law of the state or ordinance of the city.
(Ord. 23, passed 7-7-03)
   (D)   No person shall willfully, mischievously, or maliciously disfigure,
deface, or in any manner mutilate, or sit or lean upon any monument or part
thereof erected to the memory of soldiers and pioneers of the county, in the
city.
(Ord. 36, passed 12-3-23)
(‘67 Code, § 92.01)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 130.02 REWARD FOR INFORMATION CONCERNING SAFETY DEVICES.
   The Clerk-Treasurer is authorized to pay upon an ordinance duly passed by
the Common Council, a reward in the sum of $10 to any person furnishing
information or evidence which leads to the arrest and conviction of any person
or persons guilty of damaging, injuring, or theft of any red lantern, torch, or
other sign or signal of the city which is placed at any point or location to
indicate danger, to show that a dangerous condition exists, or to warn the
public of a dangerous condition, and for the theft, damage to, or removal of
any sign or signal directing traffic in the city.
(‘67 Code, § 92.02) (Ord. 13-1935, passed 3-5-35)
CHAPTER 131: OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC ORDER
Section
   
131.01   Curfew
   
131.02   Skateboards prohibited in Thornton Park
   
131.03   Nude and semi-nude acts in commercial establishments where alcoholic
beverages sold prohibited
   
131.04   Bicycles prohibited inside skate park within Thornton Park
   
131.05   Prohibiting the discharge of firearms or shooting of arrows by bow in
city parks by unauthorized persons
   
131.06   Prohibiting solicitation and distribution of materials on public
streets and roadways
   
131.07   Loitering
   
131.08   Noise control
 
   
131.99   Penalty
§ 131.01 CURFEW.
   (A)   It is a curfew violation for a child 15, 16, or 17 years of age to be
in a public place within the city:
      (1)   Between 12:01 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. on Saturday or Sunday;
      (2)   After 11:00 p.m. on Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, or
Thursday; or
      (3)   Before 5:00 a.m. on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, or
Friday.
   (B)   It is a curfew violation for a child under 15 years of age to be in a
public place within the city after 10:00 p.m. or before 5:00 a.m. on any day.
   (C)   This section does not apply to a child who is:
      (1)   Accompanied by his parent, guardian, or custodian;
      (2)   Accompanied by an adult specified by his parent, guardian, or
custodian; or
      (3)   Participating in, going to, or returning from:
         (a)   Lawful employment;
         (b)   A school-sanctioned activity; or
         (c)   A religious event.
(Ord. 31-1985, passed 1-15-86)
Penalty, see § 131.99
§ 131.02 SKATEBOARDS PROHIBITED IN THORNTON PARK.
   No skateboards shall be permitted in Thornton Park at any time, except in
areas specifically designated by signage for skateboarding.
(Ord. 20-1992, passed 7-14-92; Am. Ord. 13-2003, passed 8-12-03)
Penalty, see § 131.99
§ 131.03 NUDE AND SEMI-NUDE ACTS IN COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENTS WHERE ALCOHOLIC
BEVERAGES SOLD PROHIBITED.
   (A)   The following acts shall be prohibited and it shall be unlawful and a
violation of this section for any person maintaining, owning or operating a
commercial establishment located within the corporate limits of the city at
which alcoholic beverages are offered for sale for consumption upon the
premises:
      (1)   To suffer or permit any female person, while on the premises of
said commercial establishment, to expose to the public view that portion of the
human female breast at or below the top of the areola thereof.
      (2)   To suffer or permit any female person, while on the premises of
said commercial establishment, to employ any device of covering which is
intended to give the appearance of or simulate such portions of, the female
breast as described in subdivision (A)(1) above.
      (3)   To suffer or permit any male or female person, while on the
premises of said commercial establishment, to expose to public view his or her
genitals, pubic area, buttocks, anus or anal cleft or anal cleavage.
      (4)   To suffer or permit any person while on the premises of said
commercial establishment to employ any device or covering which is intended to
give the appearance of, or simulate, the genitals, pubic area, buttocks, anus
or anal cleft or anal cleavage.
      (5)   A violation of this section may be punished by a fine of not less
than $100 and not more than $2,500 per occurrence.
   (B)   This section shall be in full force and effect from and after February
1, 1997.
   (C)   This section shall not apply to any commercial establishments where
alcoholic beverages are served where dancing acts have been performed prior to
the date of the passage of this section.
(Ord. 1-1997, passed 1-14-97)
Penalty, see § 131.99
§ 131.04 BICYCLES PROHIBITED IN SKATE PARK WITHIN THORNTON PARK.
   (A)   No bicycle shall be allowed within the skate park located at Thornton
Park.
   (B)   Any bicycle that is either found inside the skate park or that is
observed as being inside the skate park shall be impounded by the city police
and held for a period of 30 days.
   (C)   Upon the expiration of the 30-day impoundment period, the Police
Department shall release the impounded bicycle to the owner upon the proper
identification of the bicycle by its owner.
(Ord. 25-2003, passed 10-14-03)
Penalty, see § 131.99
§ 131.05 PROHIBITING THE DISCHARGE OF FIREARMS OR SHOOTING OF ARROWS BY BOW IN
CITY PARKS BY UNAUTHORIZED PERSONS.
   (A)   The discharge of firearms and the shooting of arrows by bow in the
city parks by any person or entity without the prior written authorization of
the Park and Recreation Board is hereby prohibited.
   (B)   This section does not apply to law enforcement officers acting within
the scope of their employment.
   (C)   A violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of not less
than $50 nor more than $1,000.
   (D)   Each day of any such prohibited act shall be deemed a separate
violation.
(Ord. 6-2005, passed 2-8-05)
Penalty, see § 131.99
§ 131.06 PROHIBITING SOLICITATION AND DISTRIBUTION OF MATERIALS ON PUBLIC
STREETS AND ROADWAYS.
   (A)   The solicitation of funds by pedestrians from motorists; the sale of
goods and services by pedestrians to motorists; the performance of unrequested
services by pedestrians for motorists; and, the distribution of written
materials of any type or nature by pedestrians to motorists on any public
street, alley or roadway located within the corporate limits of the City of
Bedford, are prohibited.
   (B)   This section further prohibits pedestrians from performing the
activities prohibited by division (A) while standing in, or on public areas
contiguous to public streets, alleys or roadways located within the corporate
limits of the City of Bedford.
(Ord. 6-2006, passed 4-11-06)
Penalty, see § 131.99
§ 131.07 LOITERING.
   (A)   Remaining on a public street, sidewalk, or pathway, including one
privately owned but used by the public in general, so as to obstruct the free
passage of a pedestrian or vehicle after a regular or special police officer
has notified the person that the action is unlawful and has requested the
person to move is hereby prohibited.
   (B)   Remaining in or on a vehicle on a public street, sidewalk, or pathway,
including one privately owned but used by the public in general, so as to
obstruct the free passage of a pedestrian or vehicle after a regular or special
police officer has notified the person that the action is unlawful and has
requested the person to move is hereby prohibited.
   (C)   Refusing or failing to leave a private business, commercial
establishment, or parking lot that is posted with conspicuous “No Loitering”
signs if the business or establishment is not open for business and the person
has been requested to leave by the owner, the owner’s agent, or a regular or
special police officer, unless the person: (i) has written permission from the
owner, lessee, or operator to be present or (ii) is window shopping under
conditions and at a time of the day or night that would be considered conducive
to that activity, is hereby prohibited.
   (D)   Refusing or failing to leave a private business or commercial
establishment that is open for business, or a parking lot of the business or
establishment, after having been requested to do so by the owner or the owner’s
agent is hereby prohibited.
   (E)   Refusing or failing to leave a public building, public grounds, or a
public recreational area, or a parking lot of a public building, public
grounds, or a public recreational area, after being requested to do so by a
regular or special police officer or by a regularly employed guard, watchman,
or other authorized employee of the agency or institution responsible for the
public building, public grounds, recreational area, or parking lot, if the
circumstances indicate that the person has no apparent lawful business or
purpose to pursue at that place is hereby prohibited.
   (F)   Returning for no apparent lawful business or purpose, to the same
public or private property from which the person was asked to leave within 24
hours before is hereby prohibited.
   (G)   This section does not prohibit picketing or orderly demonstration by
labor unions or members of the public.
   (H)   All citations and payments made for violations of this section shall
be processed through the Ordinance Violations Bureau of the city.
(Ord. 19-2009, passed 7-14-09)
Penalty, see § 131.99
§ 131.08 NOISE CONTROL.
   (A)   Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following
definitions shall apply, unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.
      (1)   BAFFLE. A device to deflect, check or regulate the flow or passage
of sound.
      (2)   EMERGENCY WORK. Work made necessary to restore property to a safe
condition following a public calamity or work required to protect persons or
property from an imminent exposure to danger or work by private or public
utilities when restoring utility service.
      (3)   MOTOR VEHICLES. Means and includes any and all self-propelled
vehicles as defined by I.C. 9-13-2-105(a).
      (4)   MUFFLER. Any device used upon a motor vehicle whose purpose is the
deadening of combustion noises  of any engine thereon, or the deadening of any
other motor noises, including but not limited to the noise of exhaust gases, or
any other mechanical device for the deadening of the noise and intake gases
upon a motor vehicle.
      (5)   PERSON. A person, firm, association, co-partnership, joint venture,
corporation, or any entity, public or private in nature.
      (6)   PNEUMATIC HAMMERS. Pneumatic hammers that are driven by compressors
with greater than ten horsepower or that use a hose with a diameter greater
than three-eighths of an inch.
      (7)   PREMISES. A place in which a person has right of legal, private
occupancy.
   (B)   Noises prohibited.
      (1)   Unreasonable noise shall mean sound that is of a volume, frequency,
or pattern that prevents, disrupts, injures, or endangers the health, safety,
welfare, prosperity, comfort or repose of reasonable persons of ordinary
sensitivities within the city, given the time of day or environment in which
the sound is made.
      (2)   Except as otherwise provided, it shall be unlawful for any person
to cause or make any unreasonable noise or to allow any unreasonable noise to
be caused or made in or on any real or personal property occupied or controlled
by that person.
      (3)   In addition to the foregoing, the following acts are violations:
         (a)   It shall be a violation to operate a motor vehicle with an
internal combustion, steam or air motor unless the motor vehicle is equipped
with a suitable and efficient muffler or baffle. A muffler or baffle shall be
considered suitable and efficient when the vehicle does not create unreasonable
noise. No person while on a public or private highway, street or road shall
operate a motor vehicle with the muffler or baffle cut out or removed. No
cutout shall be so arranged or connected as to permit its operation or control
by the driver of any motor vehicle while in position for driving or by a
passenger of any motor vehicle.
         (b)   It shall be a violation for any person to use or operate
compression release engine brakes (also commonly known as "jake brakes" or
other slang term) as the primary braking system of a motor vehicle within the
municipal boundaries of the city.
         (c)   Except as used for warning purposes, it shall be a violation for
any person to use, operate or sound any horn or signaling device on any motor
vehicle in any public street or public place in the city for any unreasonable
period of time.
         (d)   It shall be a violation to play, use, or operate or allow to be
played, used, or operated in any motor vehicle any radio, television, digital
media player, loudspeaker, sound amplifier;, musical instrument, or any other
machine or device for producing or reproducing sound at a volume that is louder
than necessary for the convenient hearing of persons who are inside the vehicle
within which such device is played, used or operated between the hours of 11:00
p.m. and 8:00 a.m. Sound that is clearly audible 30 feet or more from the
vehicle is prima facie evidence of a violation of this section.
         (e)   It shall be a violation to play, use, operate or allow to be
played, used, or operated any radio, television, digital media player,
loudspeaker, sound amplifier, musical instrument, or any other machine or
device for producing or reproducing sound in such a manner that the sound
produced persists continuously or intermittently for a period of at least 15
minutes and can be heard outside the immediate premises from the location of
the emitter by a person with normal hearing. Sound that is clearly audible to a
person with normal hearing from any place other than the premises from which
the source of the sound is located, when the sound occurs between the hours of
11:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m., is prima facie evidence of a violation of this
section.
   (C)   Exemptions. The following uses and activities shall be exempt:
      (1)   Non-amplified crowd noises resulting from legal activities, between
the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m.;
      (2)   Construction operations for which building permits have been issued
or construction operations for which a permit is not required shall be exempt
from the noise control ordinance under the following conditions and with the
following exceptions:
         (a)   Such operations that occur after 6:00 a.m. and before 10:00 p.m.
However, in recognition of the work necessary to prepare and close a site each
day, motor
vehicles transporting heavy construction equipment or construction materials to
and from construction sites at those times shall be exempt from the time
restrictions set forth above;
         (b)   Because of the loud and unusual sounds, and the ground
vibrations associated with pile drivers, steam shovels, pneumatic hammers, and
steam or diesel gasoline hoists, the operation of this equipment shall be
exempt but only when it occurs between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m.;
         (c)   In order to be exempt, all equipment used in such operations
shall be operated with the manufacturer's mufflers and noise reducing equipment
in use and in proper operating condition;
      (3)   Noises of safety signals, warning devices, and emergency pressure
relief valves;
      (4)   Noises resulting from any authorized emergency, fire or police
vehicle when responding to an emergency call, acting in time of emergency or in
connection with official police or fire department business;
      (5)   Noises resulting from emergency work;
      (6)   Noises made by churches using bells as part of their religious
observance;
      (7)   Any aircraft operated in conformity with, or pursuant to, federal
law, federal air regulations, and air traffic control and instructions and
pursuant to and within the duly adopted federal air regulations. Any aircraft
operating under technical difficulties in any kind of distress, under emergency
orders of air traffic control or being operated pursuant to and subsequent to
the declaration of an emergency under federal air regulations is also exempt;
      (8)   Noises resulting from burglar alarms and other warning devices when
properly installed, providing the cause for such alarm or warning device sound
is investigated and turned off within a reasonable period of time;
      (9)   Noises resulting from rubbish collection utilizing any mechanical
equipment;
      (10)   Noises associated with equipment or animals lawfully utilized by
persons with disabilities to accommodate their disability;
      (11)   Noises associated with legal consumer fireworks used during the
times Indiana Code prohibits regulation by municipalities, which are as
follows:
         (a)   Between the hours of 5:00 p.m. until two hours after sunset on
June 29th to July 3rd;
         (b)   Between the hours of 10:00 a.m. to midnight on July 4;
         (c)   Between the hours of 5:00 p.m. until two hours after sunset on
July 5 to July 9; and
         (d)   Between the hours of 10:00 a.m. on December 31 to 1:00 a.m. on
January 1.
      (12)   Any other noise resulting from activities of a temporary duration
permitted by law and for which a permit has been granted by the city as set
forth below. Regulation of noises emanating from operations under permit shall
be according to the conditions and limits stated on the permit.
   (D)   Permits. The Chief of Police for the city, or his designated agent,
may grant a temporary permit authorizing an activity within the city that would
otherwise violate this section. A person requesting a permit must submit an
application on a form proscribed by the city and pay a permit fee of $25 to the
city at least 14 days in advance of the permit taking effect. The Chief of
Police, or his designated agent, shall have full discretion to either grant or
deny the application. If granted, the Chief ofPolice, or his designated agent,
shall issue a permit and include on the permit a reasonable expiration date and
restrictions for the activity.
   (E)   Penalties. Enforcement and the amount of any penalties for offenses
under this section shall be in accordance with the provisions of Bedford City
Code §
32.140(J).
(Ord. 12-2020, passed 9-21-20)
§ 131.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter to which no other
specific penalty applies shall be punished as set forth in §
10.99 and/or in §§
32.135 through
32.140.
   (B)   Any person who violates §
131.07 shall pay a fine of $25.00 per violation if paid within 10 days of the
date of the violation, $50.00 thereafter to be paid within 30 days of the date
of the violation. If the person who is issued an ordinance violation citation
wishes to deny the violation, or fails to pay the violation within 30 days of
the date of the violation, the citation shall be dismissed from the Ordinance
Violations Bureau and shall be re-filed with the Lawrence County Prosecuting
Attorney’s Office or the City Attorney for filing as a separate cause of action
in the appropriate Court.
(Ord. 20-1992, passed 7-14-92; Am. Ord. 6-2006, passed 4-11-06; Am. Ord. 14-
2009, passed 5-12-09; Ord. 19-2009, passed 7-14-09)
